Division II Department of Parks and Recreation.
Sec. 2-48 Department of Parks and Recreation Created.  14
   A Department of Parks and Recreation of the Town of Schererville, Lake
County, Indiana, is created.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-1)
 
Notes
14    I.C., § 36-10-3-1, et seq., sets forth the enabling legislation addressing
   parks and recreation.
Sec. 2-49 Definitions.
   The definitions herein shall apply throughout this Division, namely:
   a.   Town means Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana.
   b.   Town Council refers to the Town Council of the Town of Schererville.
15
   c.   Board refers to the Parks and Recreation Board created hereunder.
   d.   Department refers to the Department of Parks and Recreation created
hereunder.
   e.   Superintendent refers to the Administrative Head of the Department of
Parks and Recreation.
   f.   District means the area within the jurisdiction of the Department of
Parks and Recreation.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 2, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-2)
 
Notes
      Editor's Note: Ord. No. 1048 used the term "Town Board" which has been
15 replaced with "Town Council," throughout this Division to be consistent with
   current Indiana law; sec also §
   5-2 of the Code.
Sec. 2-50 Parks and Recreation Board; Membership; Appointment.
   a.   A municipal board consists of four (4) members to be appointed by the
Town Council President. The members shall be appointed on the basis of their
interest in and knowledge of parks and recreation, but no more than two (2)
members may be affiliated with the same political party. Two (2) ex officio
members may be appointed as follows:
      1.   A member of the governing body of the school corporation selected by
that body;
      2.   A member of the governing body of the library district selected by
that body; or
      3.   Both (1) and (2).
   b.   Ex officio members shall have all the rights of regular members,
including the right to vote. A vacancy in an ex officio position shall be
filled by the appointing authority.
   c.   Neither the Town Council President nor a member of a county fiscal
body, county executive, or the Town Council may serve on the Board.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 3, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-3)
Sec. 2-51 Board of Parks and Recreation; Initial Appointments; Vacancies.
   a.   The initial appointments to the Board of Parks and Recreation shall be
as follows:
      1.   One (1) member for a term of one (1) year.
      2.   One (1) member for a term of two (2) years.
      3.   One (1) member for a term of three (3) years.
      4.   One (1) member for a term of four (4) years.
   As a term expires, each new appointment is for a four (4) year term. All
terms expire on the first Monday in January, but a member shall continue in
office until his successor is appoint ed.
   b.   The Town Council President shall make initial appointments within
ninety (90) days after the creation of the Board.
   c.   In the event an appointment for any new term is not made by the first
Monday in April, the incumbent shall serve another term.
   d.   In making initial appointments, as described herein, the Town Council
President, in order to provide continuity of experience and programs, shall
give special consideration to the appointment of members from previous Boards.
   e.   In the event a vacancy on the Board occurs, the Town Council President
shall appoint a person to serve for the remainder of the unexpired term.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 4, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-4)
Sec. 2-52 Board of Parks and Recreation; Removal; Procedure.
   A member may be removed from the Board only for cause, upon specific written
charges filed against him. The charges shall be filed with and heard by the
Town Council President, unless the Town Council President is bringing the
charges. If the Town Council President is bringing the charges, the Town
Council shall appoint a hearing officer. The person to hear the charges shall
fix a date for a public hearing and give public notice at least ten (10) days
in advance of the hearing. At the hearing the member is entitled to present
evidence and argument and to be represented by counsel.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 5, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-5)
Sec. 2-53 Board of Parks and Recreation; Advisory Member.
   The Town Board of Parks and Recreation may designate a member to sit with
the Lake County Board of Parks and Recreation in an advisory capacity, but only
in the event that a member of the Lake County Board of Parks and Recreation
designates a member to sit with the Town Council of Parks and Recreation in an
advisory capacity.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 6, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-6)
Sec. 2-54 Regular and Special Meetings; Election of Officers; Quorum of the
Board.
   a.   All meetings of the Board are open to the public. The Board shall fix
the time and place of its regular meetings, but it shall meet at least
quarterly.
   b.   Special meetings of the Board may be called by the President or by any
two (2) members by written request to the Secretary. The Secretary shall send
to each member, at least two (2) days before a special meeting, a written
notice fixing the time, place, and purpose of the meeting. Written notice of a
special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting is fixed at
a regular meeting or if all members are present at the special meeting.
   c.   At its first regular meeting each year the Board shall elect a
President and a Vice President. The Vice President may act as President during
the absence or disability of the President. The Board may select a Secretary
either from within or outside its membership.
   d.   A majority of the members constitutes a quorum. Action of the Board is
not official unless it is authorized by at least three (3) members present and
acting.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 7, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-7)
Sec. 2-55 Compensation of Board Members.  16
   a.   The members of the Board may receive a salary not to exceed the maximum
amount set by annual ordinance passed by the Town Council.
   b.   In the event the Board determines that members or employees should
attend a state, regional, or national conference dealing with park and
recreation problems, it may authorize the payment of the actual expenses
involved in attending the conference. However, the amount must be available as
part of the Board's appropriation.
   c.   The Town Council shall provide suitable quarters for holding meetings
and conducting the work of the Board.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 8, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-8)
 
Notes
16    I.C., § 36-10-3-9, provides lhat board members "may receive a salary not to
   exceed three hundred ($300.00) dollars per year".
Sec. 2-56 Board Duties.
   a.   The Board shall:
      1.   Exercise general supervision of and make rules for the Department;
      2.   Establish rules governing the use of the parks and recreation
facilities by the public;
      3.   Provide police protection for its property and activities, either by
requesting assistance from state, municipal, or county police authorities, or
by having specified employees deputized as police officers; the deputized
employees, however, are not eligible for police pension benefits or other
emoluments of police officers;
      4.   Appoint the necessary administrative officers of the Department and
fix their duties;
      5.   Establish standards and qualifications for the appointment of all
personnel and approve their appointments without regard to politics;
      6.   Make recommendations and an annual report to the Town Council
concerning the operation of the Board and the status of parks and recreation
programs in the Town;
      7.   Prepare and submit an annual budget in the same manner as other
departments of the Town; and
      8.   Appoint a member of the Board to serve on another kind of board or
commission, whenever a statute allows a Board to so appoint.
   b.   The Board shall fix the compensation of officers and personnel
appointed pursuant to the authority granted herein, and in compliance with
Indiana Code, 36-4-7-5 and 36-4-7-6, as amended from time to time, and all
other applicable law.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 9, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-9)
Sec. 2-57 Board Powers.
   a.   The Board may:
      1.   Enter into contracts and leases for facilities and services;
      2.   Contract with persons for joint use of facilities for the operation
of parks and recreation programs and related services;
      3.   Contract with another Board, or a school corporation, Town Council,
Township, or County, for the use of park and recreation facilities or services,
and a township or school corporation may contract with the Board for the use of
parks and recreation facilities and services;
      4.   Acquire and dispose of real and personal property, either within or
outside the State of Indiana;
      5.   Exercise the power of eminent domain under statutes available to
Towns;
      6.   Sell, lease, or enter into a royalty contract for the natural or
mineral resources of land that it owns, the money received to be deposited in a
non-reverting capital fund of the Board;
      7.   Engage in self-supporting activities as prescribed by the provisions
of this Division;
      8.   Contract for special and temporary services and for professional
assistance;
      9.   Delegate authority to perform ministerial acts in all cases except
where final action of the Board is necessary;
      10.   Prepare, publish, and distribute reports and other materials
relating to activities authorized by this Division;
      11.   Sue and be sued collectively by its legal name, as the "Town of
Schererville Parks and Recreation Board", with service of process being had
upon the President of the Board, but costs may not be taxed against the Board
or its members in any action;
      12.   Invoke any legal, equitable, or special remedy for the enforcement
of this Division, or the Board's own action taken hereunder; and
      13.   Release and transfer, by resolution, a part of the area over which
it has jurisdiction for parks and recreational purposes to park authorities of
the County or Township, or another Town, for parks and recreational purposes
upon petition of the park or recreation Board of the acquiring County, Township
or Town.
   b.   The Board may also lease any buildings or grounds belonging to the Town
and located within a park to a person for a period not to exceed twenty-five
(25) years. The lease may authorize the lessee to provide upon the premises
educational, research, veterinary, or other proper facilities for the
exhibition of wild or domestic animals in wildlife parks, dining facilities,
swimming facilities, golf courses, skating facilities, dancing facilities, or
amusement rides generally found in amusement parks, or other recreational
facilities. A lease may be made for more than one (1) year only to the highest
and best bidder, after notice that the lease will be made has been given by
publication in accordance with Indiana Code, § 5-3-1, et seq., as amended from
time to time.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 10, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-10)
Sec. 2-58 Sale of Surplus Property; Notice.
   The Board may sell, or order sold through a designated representative, by
public or private sale, any personal property that the Board has declared to be
surplus at a regular or special meeting and has declared to be surplus at a
regular or special meeting and has declared to have an aggregate appraised
value of Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000.00) or less. Whenever the Board decides
to sell at a private sale, the Board must employ a qualified appraiser to
determine a reasonable selling price for each kind of surplus items and must
publish, in the manner provided in Indiana Code, § 5-3-1, et seq., as amended
from time to time:
   a.   The fact that a private sale will be held;
   b.   The location of the sale;
   c.   The dates of the beginning and end of the sale;
   d.   The time of day during which the sale will take place;
   e.   The kinds of items to be sold at the sale; and
   f.   The price of each kind of item, which may not be less than the
reasonable selling price determined by the qualified appraiser.
   In the event the Board decides to sell at a public sale, the Board shall
conduct the sale in the manner provided by law for the Town.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 11, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-11)
Sec. 2-59 Superintendent of Parks and Recreation; Appointment and
Qualifications.  17
   a.   The Board may appoint a Superintendent of Parks and Recreation. The
Board may not consider political affiliation in the selection of the
Superintendent.
   b.   The Superintendent must:
      1.   Be qualified by training or experience in the field of parks and
recreation; or
      2.   Have a certification or an advanced degree in the field of parks and
recreation.
   c.   An incumbent performing park and recreation functions in a supervisory
capacity at the time the Town Council adopts the Ordinance herein is eligible
for appointment as Superintendent or as an assistant, but the incumbent must
have the required training, experience, or certification.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 12, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-12)
 
Notes
      I.C., § 36-10-3-13, addresses Superintendents of Paries and Recreation. It
17 authorizes the Board to appoint the Superintendent and sets forth the
   Superintendent's qualifications.
Sec. 2-60 Assistants.
   a.   In the event the Board determines that the size of the Department's
operation requires assistants for the Superintendent, the Board may appoint,
upon the recommendation of the Superintendent, one (1) or more assistants. The
Board shall determine the qualifications on a basis similar to that prescribed
for the Superintendent.
   b.   Assistants are directly responsible to the Superintendent and shall
perform the duties specified by the Superintendent.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 13, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-13)
Sec. 2-61 Bonds of Park Officers and Employees.
   a.   Each officer and employee who handles money in the performance of his
duties as prescribed by this Division shall execute an official bond for the
term of his office or employment before entering upon the duties of his office
or employment. In the event tenure is indeterminate, then the bond must be for
a term of one (I) year and renewed each year as the employment continues.
   b.   All bonds must be individual surety company public official bonds
conditioned on the faithful performance of duties. The penal amounts of the
bonds shall be fixed by the Town Council.
   c.   All bonds shall be filed and recorded in the Office of the County
Recorder of the county in which the Department is located.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 14, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-14)
Sec. 2-62 Gifts, Donations and Subsidies.
   a.   The Board may accept gifts, donations and subsidies for park and
recreational purposes. However, a gift or transfer of property to the Board may
not be made without its approval.
   b.   A gift or grant of money shall be deposited in a special non-reverting
fund to be available for expenditure by the Board for purposes specified by the
Grantor. The disbursing officer of the Town may draw warrants against the fund
only upon vouchers signed by the President and Secretary of the Board.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 16, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-16)
Sec. 2-63 Taxing District for Special Benefit Taxes.
   a.   The territory within the boundaries of the Town compromises a special
taxing district for the purpose of levying special benefit taxes for park and
recreational purposes as provided in this Division.
   b.   The Town Council shall determine and provide the revenues necessary for
the operation of the Department or for capital expenditures not covered by the
issuance of bonds by:
      1.   A specific levy to be used exclusively for these purposes;
      2.   A special appropriation; or
      3.   Both of these methods.
(Ord. No. 1048, $ 17, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-17)
Sec. 2-64 Establishment Procedures for a Special Non-Reverting Capital Fund.
   a.   Upon the request of the Board, the Town Council shall establish, by
ordinance, a special non-reverting capital fund for the purposes of acquiring
land or making specific capital improvements. The Town Council may include in
the Board's annual budget an item and an appropriation for these specific
purposes.
   b.   Money placed in the non-reverting capital fund may not be withdrawn
except for the purposes for which the fund was created, unless the Town Council
repeals the Ordinance. The Town Council may not repeal the Ordinance under
suspension of the rules.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 18, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-18)
Sec. 2-65 Establishment Procedures for a Cumulative Building Fund.
   a.   The Board may establish a cumulative building fund to provide money
for;
      1.   Building, remodeling, and repair of parks and recreation facilities;
or
      2.   Purchase of land for parks and recreation purposes.
   Before a fund may be established, the proposed action must be approved by
the State Board of Tax Commissioners. In the event a cumulative building fund
is established, it shall be administered pursuant to the provisions set forth
in Indiana Code, § 36-10-3-21 (a) - (g), as amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 19, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-19)
Sec. 2-66 Fees for Particular Activities; Disposition and Disbursements.
   a.   Parks and recreation facilities and programs shall be made available to
the public of charge as far as possible. However, in the event it is necessary
in order to provide a particular activity, the Board may charge a reasonable
fee.
   b.   The Town Council may establish by Ordinance, upon request of the Board:
      1.   A special non-reverting operating fund for park purposes from which
expenditures may be made as provided by Ordinance, either by appropriation by
the Board or by the Town Council; or
      2.   A special non-reverting capital fund for the purpose of acquiring
land or making specific capital improvements from which expenditures may be
made appropriation by the Town Council. The Town Council shall designate the
fund or funds into which the Town Clerk-Treasurer shall deposit fees from golf
courses, swimming pools, skating rinks, or other similar facilities requiring
major expenditures for management and maintenance. Money received from fees
other than from major facilities or received from the sale of surplus property
shall be deposited by the Town Clerk-Treasurer either in the special non-
reverting operating fund or in the non-reverting capital fund, as directed by
the Board. However, in the event neither fund has been established, money
received from fees or from the sale of surplus property shall be deposited in
the Town General Fund. Money from either special fund may be disbursed only on
approved claims allowed and signed by the President and Secretary of the Board.
   c.   Money placed in the special non-reverting capital fund may not be
withdrawn except for the purposes for which the fund was created, unless the
Town Council repeals the Ordinance creating the fund. The Town Council may not
repeal the Ordinance under suspension of the rules.
   d.   Money procured from fees or received from the sale of surplus property
under this Division shall be deposited at least once each month with the Town
Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 20, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-20)
Sec. 2-67 Advisory Council and Special Committees.
   a.   The Board may create an Advisory Council and special committees
composed of citizens interested in parks and recreation.
   b.   In selecting an Advisory Council or special committees, the Board shall
give consideration to the groups in the community particularly interested in
parks and recreation. In a resolution creating an Advisory Council or a special
committee, the Board shall specify the terms of its members and the purpose for
which it is created.
   c.   The advisory council or a special committee shall:
      1.   Study the subjects and problems specified by the Board and recommend
to the Board additional problems in need of study;
      2.   Advise the Board concerning these subjects, particularly as they
relate to different areas and groups in the community; and
      3.   Upon the invitation of the Board, sit with and participate in the
deliberations of the Board, but without the right to vote.
   d.   The Advisory Council or a special committee shall report only to the
Board and shall make inquiries and reports only in those areas specified by the
Board's resolution creating the council or committee.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 21, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-21)
Sec. 2-68 Legal Authority.
   The Town Department of Parks and Recreation shall have the authority to do
any and all acts permitted by law, and particularly Indiana Code, § 36-10-3, et
seq., as amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 22, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-22)
Sec. 2-69 Repeal of Conflicting Laws.
   All existing Ordinances, Resolutions, or parts thereof, creating separate
Parks and Recreation Authorities, if any, are repealed.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 23, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-23)
Sec. 2-70 Transfer of Documents.
   All papers, documents and other property of prior Park and Recreation
Authorities shall be transferred to and become the property of the Town of
Schererville Parks and Recreation Board.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 24, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-24)
Sec. 2-71 Severability.
   If any section, clause, provision or portion of this Division shall be held
to be invalid or unconstitutional by any Court of competent jurisdiction, such
decision shall not affect any other section, clause, provision or portion of
this Division.
(Ord. No. 1048, § 25, 11-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 2-7-25)
Sec. 2-72 Special Non-Reverting Operating Fund.  18
   a.   There is created a special non-reverting operating fund for the
Department of Parks & Recreation of the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1323, § 1, 12-13-95)
   b.   Said fund is created and directed to be maintained pursuant to the
guidelines and procedures established by the State Board of Accounts for the
operation and maintenance of said non-reverting operating fund.
(Ord. No. 1323, § 2,12-13-95)
 
Notes
18    Editor's Note: Park & Recreation Board Res. No. 95-1, dated September 14,
   1995 recommended a special non-reverting operating fund.
Sec. 2-73 through Sec. 2-79 Reserved for Future Use.
Division III. Metropolitan Police Department.
Sec. 2-80 Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners.  19
   a.   The membership of the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners of the
Town of Schererville is designated as five (5), pursuant to Indiana Code, § 36-
8-9-3(b).
(Ord. No. 1194, § 2, 11-18-91)
   b.   The members of the Town Council shall hereafter name two (2) additional
members to the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners, whose terms shall
commence on the 1st day of January, 1991. The additional commissioners may not
be members of the same political party.
(Ord. No. 1194, § 3, 11-18-91)
   c.   One (1) Commissioner so appointed shall serve for a period of one (1)
year, and the other shall serve for a period of two (2) years from date of the
initial appointment. At the expiration of each Commissioner's term, unless the
same is terminated for cause prior to such expiration, a replacement
Commissioner (or re-appointment) shall be appointed to serve a three (3) year
term. Pursuant to law, each Commissioner is subject to removal by the members
of the Town Council for any cause that is deemed sufficient.
(Ord No. 1194, § 4, 11-18-91)
 
Notes
      Editor's Note: Ord. No. 378, passed on January 1, 1994, formally abolished
19 the Office of Town Marshall and established the first Board of Metropolitan
   Police Commissioners.
Sec. 2-81 Procedure to Advertise for Employment of Certified Police Officers.
   a.   The Town Council for the Town of Schererville, Indiana, may ratify a
Resolution of the Metropolitan Police Commission, and may authorize said Police
Commission to advertise for the hiring of police officers outside the
department with police academy training for the purposes of filling vacancies
existing in the Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1152, § 1,7-11-90)
   b.   The Town Council may authorize the Police Commission to offer the
inducements set forth in appropriate Resolution form in order to attract
qualified police officers to the Town of Schererville, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1152, § 2, 7-11-90)
   c.   The Town Council hereafter authorizes the metropolitan Police
Commission of the Town of Schererville, Indiana, to advertise for the
employment of officers outside the Town of Schererville with police academy
training, should said Commission feel that the situation merits such steps.
(Ord. No. 1152, § 3, 7-11-90)
Sec. 2-82 Definitions Used in the Police Department.  20
   a.   Chief shall mean the Chief of Police of the Town of Schererville,
Indiana.
   b.   Council shall mean the Town Council of the Town of Schererville,
Indiana.
   c.   Town shall mean the Town of Schererville, Indiana.
   d.   Commission shall mean the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners of
the Town of Schererville, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1112, § 1, 6-14-89; Schererville Town Code, § 2-11-1-1)

Sec. 2-84 Chief of Police.
   a.   The Chief shall have the powers and duties conferred upon all chiefs of
police under Indiana Code, § 36-8-3-10, and other applicable Indiana Code
sections, subject to the terms and conditions of this Division.
   b.   The Chief is responsible to the Town Council and the Commission to the
extent authorized by statute or other law, rule or regulation .
   c.   The Chief shall supervise the day to day activities of the police
department pursuant to law, rule or regulation.
   d.   The Chief shall assist the Council and the Commission in implementing
the policies of the Council and Commission.
   e.   The Chief shall assist the Commission in implementing and carrying out
the rules, regulations, and discipline of the police department.
(Ord. No. 1112, § 4, 6-14-89; Schererville Town Code, § 2-11-1-4)
Sec. 2-85 Rules of Interpretation.
   a.   Whenever the singular is used or the plural is used and it is more
appropriate to use the other, it may be substituted.
   b.   Whenever the male gender is referred to or the female gender is
referred to and it is more appropriate to use the other, it may be substituted.
   c.   Should any section, paragraph, clause, term, or condition herein be
declared unlawful, unenforceable or term shall be stricken or excised without
nullifying or affecting the remainder of this Division.
(Ord. No. 1112, § 5, 6-14-89)

Chapter 6 of this Code, and specific traffic regulations enforced by the Police
Department are set forth in
Chapter 8 of this Code.
Sec. 2-87 Uniform Allowance for Civilian Fire and Police Employees.
   All civilian employees of the Town of Schererville Police Department and
Fire Department shall be allowed a clothing allowance of up to two hundred and
fifty dollars ($250.00) per year. The clothing shall be purchased through the
Town of Schererville purchase order system. Any difference in the cost of
clothing and the two hundred and fifty dollar ($250.00) allotment shall remain
with the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1334A, § 1, 3-10-99)
Sec. 2-88 Uniform Allowance for Paid Full-Time Police Officers.
   a.   The Town Council for the Town of Schererville, Indiana, has provided
for a uniform allowance for its paid full-time police department of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year.
   b.   The Clerk-Treasurer for the Town of Schererville, Indiana is authorized
to issue the June quarterly uniform payment to all full-time police department
employees on an expedited basis, said amount being payable instantor.
   c.   From this point forward, the normal quarterly payments shall be
recommended regarding the uniform allowance.
(Ord. No. 1452A, §§ 1-2, 4-14-99) (See also Sec.
2-111 of this Code.)
Sec. 2-89 Police Reserve Officer Training Program.
   The Town Council approves the formation and operation of a Police Reserve
Officer Program, to be established in conformance with the provisions of
Indiana Code, § 36-8-3-20, and as such is amended hereafter from time to time.
The formation and operation of the Police Reserve Officer Program established
hereby shall commence upon adoption hereof. The Police Reserve Officer Program
General Order is appended to Ord. No. 1980, marked as Exhibit A, and is
incorporated herein by reference.
(Res. No. 2022-1, 1-12-22; Ord. No. 1980, 3-9-22)

Division IV. Policies and Procedures Governing the Metropolitan Police
Department.  21
 
Notes
      Editor's Note: The Metropolitan Police Commission adopted a Resolution on
21 April 11, 1989 recommending approval of the policies set forth in this
   Division.
Sec. 2-95 Purpose.
   To provide officers with guidelines and direction for requests for
authorized department leave.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-96   Policy.
   Officers are provided, as employee benefits, certain periods of time off
from regularly scheduled duty in the form of vacation, holiday leave, sick/
injury leave, incentive time and other leave as required by this policy.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-97 General Requirements.
   a.   Officers must request official leave on the departmental "Leave
Request" form.
      1.   Requested leave shall not be authorized without the written approval
of the Shift Supervisor and/or the Division Commander.
      2.   Leave requests should be submitted to the officer's immediate
supervisor with advanced time to consider the request and make any necessary
personnel adjustments.
         (a)   Leave decisions by supervisors are based upon personnel
availability and shift requirements.
         (b)   Appeals regarding supervisory leave decisions may be taken to
the Division Commander whose decision is final.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-98 Vacation.
   a.   An officer becomes eligible for vacation after completing one (1) year
of service. The vacation year is the calendar year. An officer's entitlement,
during the calendar year of their one (1) year anniversary will be in
accordance with the following schedule:
         Month of Hire:         Entitled to:
         January            10 Days Vacation
         February            10 Days Vacation
         March               9 Days Vacation
         April               8 Days Vacation
         May               7 Days Vacation
         June               6 Days Vacation
         Month of Hire:         Entitled to:
         July               5 Days Vacation
         August               4 Days Vacation
         September            3 Days Vacation
         October            2 Days Vacation
         November            1 Day Vacation
         December            1 Day Vacation
   b.   Officers shall receive vacation benefits based upon the following
schedule:
         Completed Years of Service:   Entitled:
         1 Year completed         10 Duty Days
         5 Years completed         15 Duty Days
         10 Years completed         20 Duty Days
      Thereafter, officers shall receive 20 duty days plus one (1) additional
duty day for each year completed beyond the (10) years of service.
      1.   Officers shall not attain in excess of twenty-five (25) duty days of
vacation regardless of years of service.
         (a)   Vacation time shall not be accrued from year to year.
      2.   Officers shall request and take accumulated vacation time during
their eligible period or have that time arbitrarily scheduled by proper
authority.
      3.   Effective January 1, 2013 all compensatory time and vacation time
may be taken on an hourly basis. However, all Holidays or incentive days must
be taken in one-half (½) days or full days.
      4.   Vacation time granted should be limited to 7 days for officers
working 12 hour shifts and 10 days for officers working 8 hour shifts.
Exceptions may be granted when work schedule and manpower allocation allows.
      5.   Vacation time requests will be authorized based on shift seniority.
      6.   Sickness/injury leave shall not be granted during vacation time.
      7.   Upon termination of employment with the Town or upon the death of an
officer, the officer shall be eligible to receive pay for any unused vacation
time in the year of termination plus vacation accrued for the following
calendar year on a prorated basis. The prorated payment will be the rate of
one-twelfth of the full vacation allotment for each full month worked in the
calendar year up to the date of termination. Such prorated application does not
apply to an officer who has been employed for a period of less than one (1)
year.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-99 Sick/Injury Leave.
   Defined as that leave granted to an officer who is physically sick or
injured to the extent that their performance would be restricted or they would
jeopardize the health of others with whom they would come in contact. This
definition also includes mental illness and surgical procedure performed at the
election of the officer as well as disease and non-duty related injury.
   a.   Officers shall earn sick/injury leave at the rate of six (6) days per
year of continuous service accrued at the rate of eighteen (18) hours per
quarter of continuous service for patrol personnel assigned to 12 hour shifts
and twelve (12) hours per quarter for personnel on 8 hour shifts.
   b.   Officers may not be allowed to accrue in excess of 1040 hours of sick/
injury leave.
   c.   Any authorized sick/injury leave taken will be deducted from the
officer's accrued total.
   d.   Paid sick/injury leave will not be granted unless the officer has
accumulated the sick/injury leave prior to sickness or injury.
      1.   Any sickness or injury that occurs without accumulated sick/injury
leave shall be without pay.
      2.   Officers shall not be allowed paid sick/leave based upon future
accruals of sick/injury leave.
   e.   The Town of Schererville, through the Chief of Police reserves the
right to require psychological or medical examination by a physician of its
choice when a department employee exceeds three (3) consecutively scheduled
work shifts on sick/injury leave.
      1.   Officers on authorized sick/injury leave shall be required to
provide any medical information required by proper department authority.
      2.   Officers on sick/injury leave may be required to sign medical
information releases if requested by proper authority.
   f.   Officers utilizing three (3) consecutively scheduled work shifts on
sick/injury leave shall provide the officer's physician's documentation
indicating nature or sickness/injury and authorization to return to work.
   g.   Misrepresentation, untruthfulness or omission regarding circumstances
of sick/injury leave requests or regarding employee's individual physical or
mental health may be considered cause for disciplinary action and/or
termination.
   h.   Routine sickness/injury leave requests require that an officer must
contact the duty supervisor who will complete the required leave form and
advise the officer's supervisor or the Division Commander.
   i.   Officer should make every effort to advise the on-duty supervisor of
sickness/injury at least two (2) hours prior to their scheduled tour of duty.
   j.   Compensation of sick/injury leave will not be paid to an officer who
retires under a disability or medical retirement.
   k.   Duty-related injury leave. Officers injured while on duty or officers
injured while engaged in authorized police actions while off-duty are covered
by the Town's Workers Compensation Insurance health plan. An officer on duty -
related injury leave shall remain on the Town payroll system receiving the same
benefits as if they were an active officer. The officer may be granted injury
leave as described below:
      1.   The Chief of Police shall be authorized at his/her sole discretion
to place an officer on duty-related injury leave status upon consultation with
the Workers Compensation physician(s). The Chief of Police shall be authorized
to evaluate and review all the facts and circumstances involving the injury
leave request and make a final determination on such request. The Board of
Safety shall be informed of the Chief of Police's decision and action and
receive monthly status reports.
      2.   Officers on duty-related injury leave may be authorized up to a
maximum of 1,040 hours of such leave at the sole discretion of the Chief of
Police, who shall utilize all related medical reports from the officer's and/or
Town's appointed physician in making the injury leave determination.
      3.   Duty-related injury leave requests may be denied based upon an
obvious full disability injury or obvious recovery time, which exceeds
available time allocated. Under such circumstances, officers may be required by
the Chief of Police to apply for disability retirement under the state
retirement plan.
      4.   Misrepresentation, untruthfulness or omission regarding
circumstances of sickness/injury leave requests may be considered cause for
disciplinary action and/or termination.
      5.   Upon recommendation of the Schererville Board of Safety, the Town
Council reserves the right to extend injury leave for duty-related injury
should the circumstances justify the same. The Town Council's determination
shall be made on a case-by-case basis and any such injury leave extension shall
be evidenced by a duly adopted resolution of the Town Council.
      6.   Any authorized, duty-related injury leave granted to individual
officers will not be deducted from their accrued sick/illness leave.
   l.   Non-duty related injury leave. 
      1.   Officers injured in a non-duty related incident and not performing a
police related action may only utilize their accrued sick/illness leave or
accrued vacation time in lieu of work.
      2.   Officers who exhaust their accrued sick/illness leave on a non-duty
related injury shall be on leave without pay status. Such officers shall also
not continue to earn vacation and sick/injury leave benefits as outlined
herein.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-100 Disability Retirement.
   a.   Officers who are unable to perform required duties and responsibilities
or who have exhausted all injury, sick/illness leave will submit disability
retirement requests to the proper Public Employees Retirement Fund as described
by applicable State Statute and administrative rules or regulation in seeking
additional retirement/disability benefits.
   b.   Officers requesting benefits will be governed by regulation, policy and
procedure as required by the State retirement fund.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-101 Military Leave.
   a.   A leave of absence with pay shall be granted to any officer who is a
member of and is required to participate in the National Guard or other reserve
components of the military service of the United States.
   b.   Military leave shall not exceed fifteen (15) duty days in any one (1)
year period.
   c.   To receive such leave, the officer shall forward notification papers
upon receipt to their Division Commander.
   d.   Activation steps.
      1.   The Chief of Police or his designee will notify a department peer
liaison member of the pending deployment.
      2.   The peer liaison member will establish contact with the member's
family to offer assistance and support throughout the deployment period.
      3.   The Chief of Police or his or her designee will be responsible for
notifying human resources to cover benefits and leave rights.
      4.   The member will be provided contact numbers for the peer liaison
member and Employee Assistance Program, as well as, phone numbers for his/her
family to contact should questions or problems regarding benefits, and the
like, by the Chief of Police or designee.
      5.   The Chief of Police or designee will meet with the member to ensure
that his/her needs are met.
      6.   The member has the option of receiving non-confidential e-mail
through his/her military account.
      7.   Provisions will be made to store the member's agency owned equipment
during their deployment.
   e.   Activation phase.
      1.   The program goal is to maintain contact as often as possible with
the activated member.
      2.   Contact may be through e-mail, packages, skype or similar medium,
and written correspondence.
      3.   The peer liaison should maintain contact with the member's family
and provide support as needed.
   f.   Deployment steps.
      1.   If available, the member may have non-confidential office e-mail
forwarded to his/her military account.
      2.   The agency will assign one voluntary member (this could be the peer
liaison member) as the point of contact for the family and the deployed member.
At a minimum, the liaison/volunteer should have contact with the family at
least once a month.
      3.   The Chief of Police or designee should avail themselves to the
family members for face to face meetings, at the family's request, to assure
needs are being addressed.
   g.   Post deployment. The agency's goal is to support the returning member
and assist with the transition back to work. The pace of re-entry will be
determined by the returning member, who will develop a transition plan with the
Chief of Police or Deputy Chief.
   h.   Work re-entry phases. Returning to work:
      1.   The Chief of Police or his designee should meet the member on the
first day of work, primarily to welcome them back, but to also discuss any
questions or areas of concerns.
      2.   The Chief of Police or designee will notify human resources of the
return and have a representative contact the member to cover benefits.
      3.   The member will be provided with appropriate peer support and
Employee Assistance Program contact number.
      4.   The member shall visit an appropriate mental health clinician
mutually agreed to by the member and the Chief of Police or designee. Time will
be granted to attend the appointment with the clinician or the Veteran's
Administration. There will be a minimum of five (5) visits to include: within
the first 2 weeks of return; at the end of reintegration; 3 months; 6 months;
and 1 year of return. An optional waiver is available for the member to
consider signing which allows for dialogue with management concerning issues of
reintegration.
      5.   The member has ninety (90) days from termination of military orders
to return to work. He/she should set the time frame to start back.
      6.   The member will be afforded use of accrued leave time for up to
thirty (30) days during this 90 day period.
      7.   Upon return to work, the member shall be put into a modified duty
status to re-adjust to daily work routines, as well as, to get reacquainted
with police changes, current issues, policies, procedures and protocols.
   i.   Sworn members. Sworn members shall not be assigned to patrol work
without first completing a reorientation period for a minimum of two weeks.
      1.   Week one return to work.
         (a)   Modified duty week.
         (b)   Member will meet with his or her appropriate commander to
obtain/reissue all necessary equipment and agency owned equipment which had
been stored during deployment.
         (c)   Member will attend mandatory briefing with human resources to
cover benefits.
         (d)   Member will obtain training facilitated by the police department
to include; first aid, control and restraint, legal updates, policy changes,
and firearms. They must also attend a mandatory meeting with a mental health
clinician.
      2.   Week two return to work.
         (a)   Upon the successful completion of week one, the member shall be
placed with a sergeant, senior officer, or upon request, a former deployed
officer (willing and available) working patrol, for a minimum of one week or an
amount of time agreed upon by the member and the Deputy Chief.
         (b)   The member shall be allowed to assist in the design of the
reintegration process in order to cover areas the member feels should be
addressed.
         (c)   The final step in the reintegration process will be a follow-up
visit to an approved mental health clinician upon completion of the
reintegration plan.
      3.   Six month follow-up.
         (a)   The member shall meet with an approved mental health clinician.
         (b)   The Chief of Police or designee will make contact with the
returning member after working in the field for six (6) months as a final
departmental check-in unless the situation dictates otherwise.
   j.   The goal should always be to support the returning member and the
member's family through the entire activation and deployment, ending with the
member's healthy transition back to work. The pace of the reentry phase will be
determined by the deployed member and the specific needs as mutually identified
by the Chief of Police or designee and the member.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-102 Emergency Leave/Bereavement Leave.
   Defined as that leave utilized in the event of death or major illness in an
officer's immediate family or any family emergency, which in the opinion of the
Chief of Police constitutes a valid emergency or bereavement leave requirement.
   a.   Immediate family shall include.
      1.   Spouse.
      2.   Child.
      3.   Parent.
      4.   Brother and sister.
      5.   Mother-in-law.
      6.   Father-in-law.
      7.   Grandparent.
      8.   Grandchild.
      9.   Stepchild.
      10.   Brother-in-law.
      11.   Sister-in-law.
   b.   Emergency bereavement leave shall be generally limited to three (3)
working days but may be extended at the discretion of the Chief of Police when
valid circumstances require additional time.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-103 Family and Medical Leave.
   a.   Employee eligibility. Family/Medical Leave of Absence (FMLA leave) is
available to employees who have been employed by the Town of Schererville for
at least one (1) year prior to the date on which FMLA leave is to commence and
who has worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12 months immediately preceding
the date on which FMLA leave is to commence.
   b.   Definitions. The terms of this section shall have the following
meanings:
      1.   Health Care Provider - A licensed physician, dentist, optometrist,
podiatrist, chiropractor, practitioner, occupational therapist or psychologist.
      2.   New Child FMLA Leave - To care for the employee's son or daughter
immediately after the birth of that son or daughter.
      3.   Family FMLA Leave - To care for the employee's spouse, son, daughter
or parent who has a serious health condition which is defined as an injury,
illness or physical or mental condition that requires inpatient hospital care
of continuing treatment by a health care provider.
      4.   Employee Medical FMLA Leave - To care for the employee's own
condition defined as a serious health condition, which renders the employee
unable to perform his or her job.
      5.   Spouse - Means a husband or wife as defined by Indiana Law.
      6.   Parent - Means a biological parent or an individual who stands or
stood in loco parentis to an employee when the employee was a child. This term
does not include parents-in-law.
      7.   Son or Daughter - Means a biological, adopted or foster child, a
stepchild, a legal ward or a child of a person standing in loco parentis, who
is either under the age 18 years of age or older and incapable of self-care
because of mental or physical disability.
   c.   FMLA leave availability. An eligible employee is entitled to FMLA Leave
as follows:
      1.   New child FMLA leave: for the birth of a child or the placement with
the employee of a child for adoption or foster care.
         (a)   FMLA leave may be taken prior to the actual birth or placement
as circumstances may require.
         (b)   An eligible employee's entitlement to FMLA Leave expires 12
months after the birth or placement.
         (c)   In the event that the parents of a son or daughter are both town
employees, they shall be entitled to a combined total of twelve (12) weeks New
Child FMLA.
      2.   Family FMLA leave: to care for the employee's seriously ill spouse,
child or parent. FMLA Leave is not available to care for unmarried domestic
partners.
      3.   Employee medical FMLA leave: due to a serious health condition that
makes the employee unable to perform his or her job functions.
   d.   Notice and certification requirements.
      1.   In cases of foreseeable medical FMLA leave, employees shall be
required to provide thirty (30) days advance FMLA leave notice and medical
certification. FMLA leave shall be denied if these requirements are not met. A
medical certification shall also be required to support an employee's request
to return to work.
      2.   In case of family FMLA leave, the town shall also require a
certification from a health care provider that the employee is needed to care
for the family member.
      3.   The town shall also require periodic reports from an employee on
FMLA leave regarding the employee's status and intent to return to work.
   e.   Implementation of FMLA leave benefits.
      1.   An eligible employee is entitled to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid
FMLA leave per 12-month period, measured backward from the date FMLA leave is
used.
      2.   An employee who has taken FMLA is entitled to be restored to the
same or an equivalent position upon his/her return to work at the end of the
FMLA leave period, except in the case of key employees. The town may deny
restoration of a key employee to that employee's position if necessary to
prevent substantial injury or disruption to the town's operations. The town
will notify employees of their status as key employees if it believes there is
a possibility that the employee will not be restored at the end of the leave
period, upon which notification the employee may voluntarily elect to return to
work.
      3.   Employees seeking FMLA leave for any purpose will be first required
to exhaust all available accrued sick leave and vacation leave. Thereafter:
         (a)   New child FMLA leave: the employee shall be eligible for the
balance of the 12 weeks FMLA leave on an unpaid basis. During the balance of
the 12 weeks, the town will pay its share and employee will pay the employee's
share of the employee's health insurance premiums.
         (b)   Family FMLA leave: the employee shall be eligible for the
balance of the 12 weeks FMLA leave on an unpaid basis. During the balance of
the 12 weeks, the town will pay its share and employee will pay the employee's
share of the employee's health insurance premiums.
         (c)   Employee medical FMLA: upon exhaustion of the entire employee's
sick and vacation days, the balance of the 12 weeks FMLA leave will be
exhausted through the use of short-term disability payments under the town's
medical benefits plan. During the balance of the 12 weeks, the town will pay
its share and the employee will pay the employee's health insurance premiums.
Upon the exhaustion of the 12 weeks, the employee may extend health insurance
coverage under COBRA.
   f.   Employment protection/limitations.
      1.   The use of FMLA Leave will not result in the loss of any employment
benefits (except accrued sick and vacation leave, as provided herein) that
accrued prior to the start of the FMLA leave.
      2.   Sick leave benefits shall not accrue during the FMLA leave. Any
vacation leave that accrues during FMLA leave shall, at that time, be taken as
a part of the approved FMLA leave.
      3.   Employees have no greater right to restoration or continuation of
benefits than if the employee had been continuously employed during the FMLA
Leave period.
      4.   If an employee fails to return to work after the employee's FMLA
leave entitlement has expired, the town may recover health insurance premiums
it paid for maintaining the employee's health insurance benefits during any
period of unpaid FMLA leave.
   g.   This policy is subject to and is to be interpreted consistent with 29
C.F.R. Part 825.
   h.   A request for leave of absence for sickness, disability or for
sabbatical purposes as addressed in I.C. 36-8-6-1 et seq. shall not be affected
by the terms of this policy and past practices and procedures governing this
state authorized leave shall continue in full force and effect.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-104 Holiday Leave.
   a.   Defined as those holidays officially recognized by the Town of
Schererville. The Schererville Police Department recognizes the following eight
(8) holidays:
      1.   New Year's Day - January 1st
      2.   Martin Luther King, Jr. Day - 3rd Monday in January
      3.   Memorial Day - May
      4.   Independence Day - July 4th
      5.   Labor Day - 1st Monday in September
      6.   Veteran's Day - November 11th
      7.   Thanksgiving Day - 4th Thursday in November
      8.   Christmas Day - December 25th
   b.   All officers assigned to work regular business hours and not assigned
to duty requiring shift work will have the option to receive the listed
holidays as days off with pay or may work the holiday and use the day as an
addition to their regular vacation benefit.
   c.   All officers assigned to work shift work, generally the Patrol
Division, will earn the above-identified floating holidays (8 days) as
additions to their regular vacation benefit.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-105 Leave of Absence.
   Defined as a leave period of extended duration without pay after exhaustion
of all accrued leave time.
   a. Leave of absence shall be requested by affected officer through the
office of the Chief of Police.
      1.   The Chief of Police's recommendation will be submitted to the
Schererville Board of Safety which will submit its recommendation to the Town
Council for final decision.
      2.   Requests must include specific leave date, duration and specific
reasons for leave of absence application.
   b.   Leave of absence will not be granted except on a without pay basis
unless otherwise defined in this policy or authorized by the Town Council.
   c.   During approved leaves of absence, employees shall be 100% responsible
for and must pay the full health insurance premium (employee contribution and
town contribution) to remain covered by the Town health insurance policy.
   d.   During approved leaves of absence, employees shall not continue to earn
either vacation time or sick/injury time.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-106 Incentive Leave Days.
   a.   Officers shall be granted incentive leave days at the rate of one (1)
duty day for each three (3) month quarterly period in which the officer records
perfect attendance.
      1.   Incentive leave days may be accumulated from year to year, up to a
maximum of twenty (20) days.
      2.   Earned incentive leave days may be authorized by the officer's
supervisor based upon workload and manpower availability and shall be scheduled
at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance.
   b.   Perfect attendance - defined as an officer appearing for, and actually
working each and every one of the officer's scheduled work shifts during a
three (3) month quarterly period.
      1.   This includes periods of authorized vacation and on-duty sickness/
injury.
      2.   Excluded are days off assessed as a result of disciplinary action,
non-duty sick/injury leave, the Family Medical Leave Act time and/or any
unauthorized leaves of absence.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-106A Retirement Procedure.
   a.   Prior to retirement, any eligible officer shall submit a letter,
through the proper chain of command, to the Chairman of the Board of Safety,
advising that said officer intends to retire and provide the effective date of
retirement.
      1.   Attached to the retirement policy is a form retirement letter. The
officer should follow the retirement letter format and provide all information
requested in same including any and all other pertinent information deemed
necessary by the officer.
   b.   Any officer having twenty (20) or more years of service meeting the
requirements for police officers of the State of Indiana and the Public
Employees Retirement Fund shall be eligible to retire from the Schererville
Police Department by selecting one (1) of the two (2) pay options below:
      1.   Lump sum final paycheck payout.
         (a)   Upon retirement from active service, including completion of the
State of Indiana continuous service requirements, the retiring officer will be
compensated at their current hourly rate of pay for the unused balance of their
accrued sickness/injury, vacation, incentive and earned holiday leave at the
time of their retirement. The compensation will be paid in a lump sum and
placed on the officer's final paycheck following the retirement date.
         (b)   A retiring officer shall be allowed to utilize accrued sickness/
injury, vacation, incentive and holiday leave as authorized by the Board of
Safety for the purpose of reaching the mandatory minimum service requirements
of the Indiana Public Employees Retirement Fund for police officers (20 years).
It is the policy of the Board of Safety that accrued days may be utilized prior
to the officer having completed twenty (20) years of service with the
department and that said time may be credited to allow the officer to reach the
twenty (20) year active service time period. Once credited and the twenty (20)
year mark has been reached, the retiring officer shall be compensated at their
current hourly rate of pay for any unused balance of their accrued sickness/
injury, vacation, incentive and earned holiday leave. The compensation will be
paid in a lump sum and be placed on the officer's final paycheck following the
retirement date.
      2.   Payment over time/remaining on town payroll. Upon retirement from
active service, an officer who was in active service on January 1, 2015 shall
be limited to the number of accrued or remaining sickness/injury, vacation,
incentive and earned holiday leave hours the officer had on record as of
January 1, 2015 for payment over time by remaining on the Town Payroll. (A list
of active duty officers and their accrued time as of January 1, 2015 is
attached hereto). Said accrued hours as of January 1, 2015 will be paid to the
retiring officer by and through the officer remaining on the Town of
Schererville payroll system for that set length of time. Any other accrued
sickness/injury, vacation, incentive and earned holiday leave time above and
beyond that which existed on January 1, 2015, shall be paid out in a lump sum
on the retired officer's final paycheck after leaving active service. A retired
officer that remains on the Town payroll as outlined herein shall also qualify
for all Town insurance benefits, longevity pay and earned holiday pay as if
still an active member of the police department.
   c.   At the time of retirement, all retired officers shall be required to
relinquish any and all equipment and/or property belonging to the Schererville
Police Department that is in his/her custody. A retired officer's clothing
allowance shall cease immediately upon end of active service/last day of duty.
   d.   Each retiring officer will be presented with a Schererville Police
Department badge. The badge will reflect the retiring officer's rank and will
be engraved "Retired". The retiring officer will also be awarded his/her
service weapon from the Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-106B Resignation Procedures.
   a.   If an officer resigns from active service prior to reaching retirement
date, any accrual of incentive time, earned holiday pay, and longevity pay
shall be paid in a lump sum and be placed on the resigned officer's final
paycheck following the resignation date.
   b.   A resigned officer's clothing allowance shall cease immediately upon
resignation from active service.
   c.   If an officer resigns from active service, the officer may submit a
written request to the Board of Safety to purchase the officer's service
weapon. The Board of Safety's decision on such a proposed purchase shall be
final.
(Ord. No. 1871, § 2, 7-8-15)
Sec. 2-107 Wages.
   All wage rates for the Police Department shall be set by annual ordinance of
the Town Council.
Sec. 2-108 Overtime.
   A Schererville Police Officer may be required to work overtime, in addition
to his or her established work period, as scheduled by the appropriate
department personnel. Overtime work is work in addition to the established
schedule of hours of work per week. Overtime shall be kept to a minimum.
Overtime work may be authorized by the appropriate department personnel only
when necessary. Police Officers may be compensated for authorized overtime by
being granted compensatory time off at the rate of one and one-half hour for
each hour worked in excess of the established and scheduled work period, or
may, at the option and election of the designated department personnel, under
the direction of the Chief of Police, be paid for such overtime work at the
rate of one and one-half the rate of regular pay for each hour of overtime
worked. Compensatory time off for an individual Schererville Police Officer
will be scheduled with the approval of the authorized department supervisory
personnel.
(Ord. No. 1164, § 1 [b] ii, 10-10-90; Ord. No. 1501, § 1, 10-11-00)
Sec. 2-109 Compensation Regarding Alcohol Counter-Measures Program.
   Compensation for hours assigned to Police Department Law Enforcement
Officers, pursuant to the Alcohol Counter-Measures Program, as provided for by
the Public Safety Council of Northwest Indiana, Inc., in the State of Indiana,
Department of Highways shall be one and one-half times the contracted hourly
rate of pay, when the hours worked by a law enforcement officer of the town
causes said officer to work in excess of the scheduled time period set forth in
Section
2-108. Compensation to police department law enforcement officers, pursuant to
the Alcohol Counter-Measures Program shall continue to be drawn upon special
reimbursement funding consistent with the policies requirements of public
safety council of Northwest Indiana, Inc., and the State of Indiana Department
of Highways.
(Ord. No. 1164, § 1[c], 10-10-90)
Sec. 2-110 Compensatory Time.
   Each individual police officer shall have the choice of electing to accept
overtime compensation as set forth herein or in lieu of overtime each
individual officer may elect to take compensatory time at the rate of one and
one-half hour of compensatory time for each hour worked in excess of the
aforementioned work periods. All civilian employees of the Schererville Police
Department as designated under Subsection A of Ordinance No. 896 shall also
have the option of electing to take compensatory time in lieu of overtime pay.
(Ord. No. 1164, § 1[d], 10-10-90)
Sec. 2-111 Uniform Allowance for Full-Time Police Officers.  23
   a.   The Town of Schererville shall each year provide a uniform allowance to
all full-time police officers or to active members of the police department,
who qualify for such allowance, or provide uniforms and/or equipment equivalent
to the amount established by ordinance.
(Ord. No. 1101, § 1, 4-12-89)
   b.   This allowance or provision of uniforms and/or equipment shall be
provided in two (2) equal installments, the dates of same being June 30th and
December 31st of each year.
   c.   Any uniform allowance or provision of uniforms and/or equipment
provided prior to passage and adoption of this ordinance are ratified and
reaffirmed.
(Ord. No. 1334, §§ 3-5, 4-10-96; Ord. No. 1502, § 1, 10-11-00; Ord. No. 1452C,
5-9-07)
   d.   All active police officers of the Town of Schererville shall either
provide or be provided with uniforms and equipment which qualifies or is
required by rule, regulation, directive, order, resolution or ordinance of the
Town of Schererville, the Metropolitan Police Commission of the Town of
Schererville, or Police Chief of the Town of Schererville.
   e.   Any uniform or equipment provided by the Town of Schererville to any
police officer shall be credited against this uniform allowance.
   f.   All uniforms, equipment, arms, or clothing either provided by the Town
of Schererville or purchased by any police officer of the Town with his uniform
allowance or as a requirement or condition of employment shall remain on the
property of the Town. The Town may sell or otherwise dispose of this property
if and when it becomes unfit, for any reason, for use, and any money received
from any sale thereof shall be placed in the general fund of the Town.
   g.   Any uniforms, equipment, arms, clothing or other property lost,
damaged, or destroyed through the carelessness or neglect of a member of the
police department of the Town shall be charged against that member and the
value thereof deducted from his pay.
(Ord. No. 1101, §§ 4-8, 4-12-89)
(See also Sec.
2-88 of this Chapter)
 
Notes
      I.C., § 36-8-4-4, addresses uniforms and equipment. The amount of $600 was
23 deleted from this paragraph at the Town's request with “the amount established by
   ordinance” being substituted as part of the recodification process. Eight hundred
   dollars ($800.00) was the amount prior to the 1999 Ordinance.

shall pay funeral benefits to the heirs or estate of any active or retired
member of the police force who has suffered death from any cause which said
funeral benefits shall be in the amount established by ordinance.
(Ord. No. 572a, § 1, 2-14-73)

Sec. 2-113 Police Department to Accept Applications for Licensing Hand Guns.
   The Police Department by and through its Chief or Acting Chief or designee
shall carry out these powers established by the Town Council regarding the
applications for licensing hand guns as more specifically addressed in
Chapter 4 of this Code.
Sec. 2-114 Deferred Prosecution Cost Into L.E.C.E.F. Fund.
   a.   The Town of Schererville, Indiana, shall designate the sum of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) to be paid from any and all monies collected as a result
of the deferred prosecution program, said sum being paid directly to the
Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1371, §§ 1-2, 2-12-97)
   b.   The Town Council now directs that all funds previously paid into the
L.E.C.E.F. Fund from the pre-trial diversion program be transferred into the
Schererville Police Department Training Fund.
   c.   The Town Council directs that the Town court continue to apply the sum
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) from each pre-trial diversion fee toward the
continuing education of Schererville Police Officers, and that said sums of
money shall be paid into the Schererville Police Department Training Fund.
(Ord. No. 1371A, §§ 1-2, 9-10-97)

in the amount of twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00).
(Ord. No. 1358, § 1, 6-13-96; Ord. No. 1358A, § 1, 6-9-99; Ord. No. 1358B, § 1,
7-9-08)

Division V. Fire Department.  25
 
Notes

25 simultaneously with the recodification and is on file in the Office of the
