Article 1. Town Council.  1
 
Notes
1 1   I.C., §§ 36-5-2-1 through 36-5-2-11, address Town legislative body and
  executive.
Division I. Background Information.
Sec. 3-1 Five (5)Member Council.
   a.   The Town Council is the Town legislative body.  2
   b.   The Town Council consists of five (5) members.  3
   c.   The members of the Town Council shall be elected at large by the
voters.
   d.   The members of the Town Council shall be residents of the district
(ward) to which they are elected to represent.
(Ord. No. 1398, § 2, 10-29-97; Ord. No. 1563, §§ 1-2, 12-12-02)
 
Notes
2 2   I.C., § 36-5-2-2, addresses the Town Council.
3 3   I.C., § 36-5-2-3, addresses the term of office of Council Members.
Sec. 3-2 Five (5) Legislative Districts (Wards)  4 ,  5
   a.   The Town of Schererville is divided into five (5) legislative districts
(wards) to be numbered District 1, District 2, District 3, District 4, and
District 5.
(Ord. No. 1398, § 1, 10-29-97)
   b.   Geographic boundaries.  6
   The geographical boundaries of the five (5) districts (wards) for the
purpose of conducting elections and determining residency of the Town Council
Members along with the population of each such district, shall be modified as
set forth on the map attached hereto as Exhibit "A," incorporated herein by
reference and specifically made part of this ordinance.
   The District (Ward) Boundaries shall be as set forth hereafter, namely:

Sec. 3-3 Terms of Office
   a.   The office of Councilman from each of all five (5) wards as well as the
Clerk-Treasurer shall run in the primary election and general elections
regularly held in a general election year during the year 1991 pursuant to
Indiana Code, §§ 3-10-6-2 and 3-10-6-3 for a four (4) year term each.
(Ord. No. 1137, § 5, 12-11-89)
   b.   Each of the terms of all Councilmen from each of the five (5) wards, as
well as the Clerk-Treasurer will then commence January 1, unless otherwise
amended by State law or further action by this Council.
See. 3-4 through Sec. 3-7 Reserved for Future Use.
Division II. Governing Regulations of the Council
Sec. 3-8 Selection of a Council President.  7
   a.   The Town Council shall select one of its members to be its president
for a definite term, which may not exceed his term of office as a member of the
legislative body.
(Schererville Town Code, § 2-4-4)
   b.   The President of the Town Council is the Town Executive.
 
Notes
7 7   I.C., § 36-5-2-7, addresses the selection of a President, and I.C., § 36-5-2-
  2, addresses the Town Executive.
Sec. 3-9 Selection of a Vice-President.
   a.   The Town Council shall select one of its members to be its vice-
president for a definite term, which may not exceed his or her term of office
as a member of the legislative body.
   b.   The Vice-President of the Town council shall serve as Executive in the
absence, sickness or illness of the President.
Sec. 3-10 Quorum.  8
   A majority of all the elected members of the Town Council constitutes a
quorum.
(Schererville Town Code, § 2-4-4)
 
Notes
8 8   I.C., § 36-5-2-9.1, defines a quorum of the Council.
Sec. 3-11 When Majority Vote Required.
   A majority vote of the Town Council is required to pass an ordinance, unless
a greater vote is required by statute. A majority vote means at least a
majority vote of all the elected members.
(Schererville Town Code, § 2-4-5)
Sec. 3-12 When Two-Thirds (2/3) Vote Required.  9
   A two-thirds (2/3) vote, with unanimous consent of the members present, is
required to pass an ordinance on the same day or at the same meeting at which
it is introduced. A two-thirds (2/3) vote means at least two-thirds (2/3) vote
of all the elected members.
 
Notes
9 9   I.C., § 36-5-2-9.8, addresses votes of the Council.
Sec. 3-13 Town Clerk-Treasurer Authorized to Break Ties.  10
   The Town Clerk-Treasurer is the clerk of the Town Council. Whenever the Town
Council has an even number of members for any reason, the Clerk-Treasurer is an
ex officio member for the purpose of casting the deciding vote to break a tie.
(Schererville Town Code, § 2-4-7)
 
Notes
10 10   I.C., § 36-5-2-8, authorizes the Clerk-Treasurer to vote in case of a
   tie.
Sec. 3-14 When an Ordinance Takes Effect.  11
   An ordinance, order, or resolution passed by the Town Council becomes
effective when signed by the president of the Council unless the ordinance,
order or resolution by its own terms establishes the date upon which it takes
effect. If required by statute, an adopted ordinance, order, or resolution must
be promulgated or published before it takes effect.
(Schererville Town Code, § 2-4-9)
 
Notes
11 11   I.C., § 36-5-2-10, addresses adoption of ordinances, orders, resolutions, and
   their publication.
Sec. 3-15 Regular and Special Meetings of the Town Council.  12
   a. The regular meetings of the Town Council shall be held at the Town Hall
in the Town of Schererville at any reasonable hour of the day or evening (such
hour, if not the usual ordinarily appointed one having been previously agreed
upon by the majority of the Council and the Clerk-Treasurer duly and promptly
notified thereof), provided that in all cases where a special meeting or called
meeting is called, at least forty-eight (48) hours written notice shall be
given to the Town Council, Clerk-Treasurer, and the public, pursuant to Indiana
Code, § 5-14-1.5.
   b.   Special or called meetings may be called by the President of the
Council, or in his absence, sickness, inability or refusal to make such call,
by the Vice-President of the Council, and in his absence, sickness, inability
or refusal to make such call, then by a majority of the Council when deemed
necessary. The President and Vice President may by verbal notice at the public
meeting, when all members of the Council are present, call a special meeting of
the Council, and in all cases where the provisions of the statutes of Indiana
regulating the calling of the special meeting do not forbid such action by
prescribing differently. In all cases where provisions of the statute prescribe
the method of the call, the provisions must be strictly followed.
   c.   Executive sessions shall be conducted in strict compliance with Indiana
Code, § 5-14-1.5-6.
 
Notes
12 12   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-1, et seq., addresses the Indiana Open Door Law.
Sec. 3-16 Powers of the Town Council.  13
   The Council may:
   a.   adopt Ordinances and Resolutions for the performance of functions of
the Town;
   b.   purchase, hold, and convey any interest in property, for the use of the
Town;
   c.   adopt and use a common seal; and
   d.   exercise all powers that are needed for the effective operation of
local governmental affairs.  14
 
Notes
13 13   I.C., § 36-5-2-9, sets forth the powers of the legislative body.
14 14   I.C., §§ 36-1-3-1 through 36-1-3-9, set forth Home Rule powers of
   municipalities.
Sec. 3-17 Order of Business at Town Council Meetings.
   The following order of business shall be followed at Town Council meetings:
   I.   Call to order and Pledge of Allegiance.
   II.   Roll Call.
   III.   Personnel Business.
   IV.   Approval of Minutes of Previous Meeting(s).
   V.   Claims.
   VI.   Old Business.
   VII.   Reports.
      1.   Staff
      2.   Council
   VIII.    New Business.
   IX.    Business for Floor.
   X.    Adjournment.
Sec. 3-18 Rules of Order.
   The most recent version of Roberts Rules of Order shall govern all meetings
of the Town Council, unless ordinance or statute provide otherwise.
Sec. 3-19 Taping and Recording of Meetings.  15
   a.   Pursuant to Indiana Code, § 36-5-2-8 the, Clerk-Treasurer of every town
shall attend all meetings of the Town Council and shall be the keeper and have
custody of the records, books, and papers of the Town Council.
   b.   The Town Council has determined that it is necessary to further protect
the legal interests of the Town of Schererville and its citizens by requiring
the Clerk-Treasurer to keep, maintain, and have custody of any and all recorded
tapes of public hearings or meetings of the Town of Schererville including, but
not limited to:
      1.   Town Council meetings.
      2.   Utility Board meetings.
   c.   Tape or tapes shall be kept by the Clerk-Treasurer for a minimum period
of one (1) year from the date of said public meeting or hearing.
(Ord. No. 851, 3-11-81; Schererville Town Code, § 2-19-2)
 
Notes
15 15   Ord. No. 851 cited I.C., § 18-3-1-31, which has been replaced by I.C., § 36-
   5-2-8.
Sec. 3-20 Town Recording Secretaries.
   The Town Recording Secretaries addressed in Section
2-172 of this Code shall work exclusively under the direction of the Town
Council and Town Manager.
Sec. 3-21 Tax Anticipation Warrant Procedures.
   The Town Council may pass ordinances authorizing the Town to borrow money
and issue tax anticipation warrants pursuant to the procedures set forth in
Section
2-370 through Section
2-377 of this Code.
Sec. 3-22 Claim Docket Procedures.
   The claim docket procedures set forth in Section
2-344 through Section
2-347 of this Code shall govern.
Sec. 3-23 Compensation of the Town Council.  16
   a.   The Town Council shall, by Ordinance, fix the compensation of its own
members.
   b.   The compensation of an elected Town officer may not be changed in the
year for which it is fixed nor may it be reduced below the amount fixed for the
previous year.
 
Notes
16 16   I.C., § 36-5-3-2, addresses the compensation for members of the Council for
   their Town officers and employees.
Sec. 3-24 Life Insurance Benefits and Coverage for Council Members.
   a.   Those members of the Town Council of the Town of Schererville, who
elect to do so, are entitled to life insurance benefits and coverage for
themselves, and eligible dependents, as offered and provided to the other
employees of the Town of Schererville, as part of the employee compensation
package.
(Ord. No. 1317, § 1, 11-8-95)
   b.   The life insurance coverage set forth in paragraph a, shall terminate
upon the expiration of term of the Council Member so electing such coverage, at
which time, said Member, and covered dependents, shall be entitled to convert
the coverage to an individual life insurance program.
(Ord. No. 1317, § 2, 11-8-95)

   All Ordinances which are of a general and permanent nature and which would
amend the Town Code, shall be in the form depicted on the following page.

Sec. 3-26 Electronic Participation in Town Council Meetings.
   a.   1.   The provisions of the Indiana Public Meeting Law (“the Act”), or
Indiana Code, § 5-14-1.5-3.5(d), and all other relevant terms of Indiana Code,
§§ 5-14-1.1-1 et seq., including definition, apply to this section.
      2.   This section shall be known as the “Electronic Meetings Policy” of
the Council, and applies to the Council and any Committee or Body appointed
directly to this Council, of its presiding Officer.
   b.   1.   Subject to the provisions of subsections c. and e. hereinafter,
any member of the Town Council may participate in a public meeting by any
electronic means of communication that:
         A.   Allows all participating members of the Governing/Legislative
body to simultaneously communicate with each other; and
         B.   Other than a public meeting that is an executive session, allows
the public to simultaneously attend and observe the public meeting.
      2.   A member who participates by an electronic means of communication:
         A.   Shall be considered present for purposes of establishing a
quorum; and
         B.   May participate in final action only if the member can be seen
and heard.
      3.   All votes taken during a public meeting at which at least one (1)
member participates by an electronic means of communication must be taken by
roll call vote.
   c.   1.   At least fifty percent (50%) of the members must be physically
present at a public meeting at which a member will participate by means of
electronic communication. Not more than fifty percent (50%) of the members may
participate by an electronic means of communication at that same public
meeting.
      2.   A member may not attend more than fifty percent (50%) of the public
meetings in a calendar year by an electronic means of communication, unless the
member’s electronic participation is due to:
         A.   Military service;
         B.   Illness or other medical condition;
         C.   Death of a relative; or
         D.   An emergency involving actual or threatened injury to person or
property.
      3.   A member may attend two (2) consecutive meetings (a set of meetings)
by electronic communication. A member must attend in person at least one (1)
public meeting between sets of public meetings that the member attends by
electronic communication, unless the member’s absence is due to:
         A.   Military service;
         B.   Illness of other medical condition;
         C.   Death of a relative; or
         D.   An emergency involving actual or threatened injury to person or
property.
   d.   The minutes or memoranda of a public meeting at which any member
participates by electronic means of communication must:
      1.   Identify each member who:
         A.   Was physically present at the meeting;
         B.   Participated in the meeting by electronic means of
communications; and/or
         C.   Was absent; and
      2.   Identify the electronic means of communication by which:
         A.   Members participated in the public meeting; and
         B.   Members of the public attended and observed the public meeting if
the public meeting was not an executive session.
   e.   No member of the Council may participate by means of electronic
communication in a public meeting at which the Council may take final action:
      1.   Adopt a budget;
      2.   Make a reduction in personnel;
      3.   Initiate a referendum;
      4.   Impose or increase a fine;
      5.   Impose or increase a penalty;
      6.   Exercise the Council’s power or eminent domain; or
      7.   Establish, impose, raise or renew a tax.
   f.   1.   In the event that an emergency is declared by:
         A.   The Governor under the provisions of Indiana Code, § 10-14-3-29,
or
         B.   The Town Council President under the provisions of Indiana Code,
§ 10-14-3-29, then members are not required to be physically present for a
public meeting until the emergency is terminated.
      2.   Members may participate in a public meeting by any means of
communication, provided that:
         A.   At least a quorum of the members participate in the public
meeting by means of electronic communication or in person;
         B.   The public may simultaneously attend and observe the public
meeting unless the meeting is an executive session; and
         C.   The minutes or memoranda of the public meeting must comply with
the provisions of subsection d. of this section, as amended from time to time.
      3.   All votes taken during a public meeting at which at least one (1)
member participates by an electronic means of communication must be taken by
roll call vote.
(Ord. No. 1981, §§ 1 - 6, 5-11-22)
Sec. 3-27 through Sec. 3-29 Reserved for Future Use.
Division III. Procedures Governing Deliberations and Actions of the Governing
Bodies of the Town.  17
 
Notes
17 17   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-8, addresses accessibility to individuals with
   disabilities under the Open Door Law.
Sec. 3-30 Definitions.  18
   a.   Governing body means any board, commission, or other legislative or
administrative body of the Town of Schererville which takes official action
upon public business and includes any committee appointed by the governing body
or its presiding officer to which authority to take official action upon public
business has been delegated.
   b.   Meeting means a gathering of a majority of a governing body of the Town
of Schererville for the purpose of taking official action upon public business.
It does not include: 1) any social or chance gathering not intended to avoid
this chapter; 2) any on-site inspection of any project or program; 3) traveling
to and attending meetings of organizations devoted to betterment of government;
or 4) a caucus.
   c.   Official action means:
      1.   to receive information or to deliberate on public business;
      2.   to make recommendations pursuant to statute, ordinance, or executive
order;
      3.   to establish policy;
      4.   to make decisions on public business; or
      5.   to take final action.
   d.   Public business means the function for which the Town of Schererville
is created.
   e.   Executive session means a meeting from which the public is excluded
except, the governing body may admit those persons necessary to carry out the
purpose of the executive session.
   f.   Final action means a vote by the governing body on any motion,
proposal, resolution, rule, regulation, ordinance, or order.
   g.   Caucus means a gathering of members of a political party or coalition
which is held for purposes of planning political strategy and holding
discussions designed to prepare the members for taking official action.
   h.   Deliberate means a discussion which may reasonably be expected to
result in official action defined under Section
3-30 'c' '2', '3', '4' or '5' of this Division.
   i.   News Media means all newspapers qualified to receive legal
advertisements under Indiana Code., § 5-3-1, all wire services and all licensed
commercial or public radio or television stations.
(Ord. No. 885, § 1, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
18 18   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-2, sets forth definitions of the Indiana Open Door
   Law.
Sec. 3-31 Open Meetings; Secret Ballot Votes.  19
   a.   Except as provided in Section
3-34 herein, all meetings of the governing bodies of public agencies must be
open at all times for the purpose of permitting members of the public to
observe and record them.
   b.   A secret ballot vote may not be taken at a meeting.
(Ord. No. 885, § 2, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
19 19   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-3, addresses open meetings and secret ballot votes.
Sec. 3-32 Posting of Agenda; Memoranda of Meetings; Public Inspection of
Minutes.  20
   a.   A governing body of the Town of Schererville utilizing an agenda shall
post a copy of the agenda at the entrance to the location of the meeting prior
to the meeting. A rule, regulation, ordinance or other final action adopted by
reference to agenda number of item alone is void.
   b.   As the meeting progresses, the following memoranda shall be kept: 1)
the date, time and place of the meeting; 2) the members of the governing body
recorded as either present or absent; 3) the general substance of all matters
proposed, discussed or decided; and 4) a record of all votes taken, by
individual members if there is a roll call. The memoranda are to be available
within a reasonable period of time after the meeting for the purpose of
informing the public of the governing body's proceedings. The minutes, if any,
are to be open for public inspection and copying.
(Ord. No. 885, § 3, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
20 20   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-4, addresses agendas and minutes.
Sec. 3-33 Public Notice of Meetings.  21
   a.   Public notice of the date, time and place of any meetings, executive
sessions, or of any rescheduled or reconvened meeting, shall be given at least
forty-eight (48) hours before the meeting; this requirement does not apply to
reconvened meetings where announcement of the date, time and place of the
reconvened meeting is made at the original meeting and recorded in the
memoranda and minutes thereof, and there is no change in the agenda.
   b.   Public notice shall be given by a governing body of the Town of
Schererville by:
      1.   posting a copy of the notice at the Town Hall of the Town of
Schererville, and at the building where the meeting is to be held; and
      2.   depositing in the United States mail with postage prepaid or by
delivering notice to all news media which file by each January 1 an annual
written request for such notices with the Town Council of the Town of
Schererville. Said media shall be entitled to receive said notices immediately
upon the filing of their written request.
   c.   Notice of regular meetings need be given only once each year, except
that an additional notice shall be given where the date, time and place of a
regular meeting or meetings is changed. This subsection does not apply in
executive sessions.
   d.   If a meeting is called to deal with an emergency involving actual or
threatened injury to person or property, or actual or threatened disruption of
the governmental activity under the jurisdiction of the Town of Schererville by
any event, then the time requirements of notice under this section shall not
apply, but:
      1.   news media which have requested notice of meetings must be given the
same notice as is given to the members of the governing body; and
      2.   the public must be notified by posting a copy of the notice
according to this section.
(Ord. No. 885, § 4, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
21 21   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-5, addresses public notice of meetings.
Sec. 3-34 Executive Sessions.  22
   a.   Executive sessions may be held only in the following instances: 1)
where authorized by federal or state statute; 2) for discussion of strategy
with respect to: collective bargaining, initiation of litigation or litigation
which is either pending or has been threatened specifically in writing, the
implementation of security systems, or the purchase or lease of real property
up to the time a contract or option to purchase or lease is executed by the
parties; however, all such strategy discussions must be necessary for
competitive or bargaining reasons; 3) interviews with industrial or commercial
prospects or their agents; 4) interviews with prospective employees; 5) with
respect to any individual over whom the governing body has jurisdiction; to
receive information concerning the individual's alleged misconduct, and to
discuss, prior to any determination, that individual's status as an employee,
student, or independent contractor, 6) for discussion of records classified as
confidential by state or federal statute; and 7) to discuss a job performance
evaluation of individual employees.
   b.   A final action must be taken at a meeting open to the public.
   c.   Public notice of executive sessions must state their purpose or subject
matter. The requirements stated in Sec.
3-32 of this chapter for memoranda and minutes being made available to the
public is modified as to executive sessions in that they need identify only the
subject considered.
   d.   A governing body may not conduct an executive session during a meeting,
except as otherwise permitted by applicable statute or ordinance. A meeting may
not be recessed and reconvened with the intent of circumventing this
subsection.
(Ord. No. 885, § 5, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
22 22   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-6.1, addresses executive sessions.
Sec. 3-35 Collective Bargaining Meetings; Applicable Requirements.  23
   Whenever a governing body, or any person or persons authorized to act for a
governing body, meets with an employee organization, or any person or persons
authorized to act for an employee organization, for the purpose of collective
bargaining or discussion, the following apply:
   a.   Any party may inform the public of the status of collective bargaining
or discussion as it progresses by release of factual information and expression
of opinion based upon factual information.
   b.   If a mediator is appointed, any report he may file at the conclusion of
mediation is a public record open to public inspection.
   c.   If a factfinder is appointed, any hearings he holds must be open at all
times for the purpose of permitting members of the public to observe and record
them. Any findings and recommendations he makes are public records open to
public inspections provided by Indiana Code, § 20-7.5-1-13(e) or any other
applicable statute relating to factfinding in connection with public collective
bargaining.
(Ord. No. 885, § 6,3-10-82)
 
Notes
23 23   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-6.5, addresses collective bargaining.
Sec. 3-36 Violations; Remedies; Limitations; Costs and Fees.  24
   a.   An action may be filed by any citizen of this state in any court of
competent jurisdiction to enjoin continuing, threatened or future violations of
this Division or to declare void any action taken at an executive session in
violation of Section
3-31 of this Division or at any meeting of which notice is not given in
accordance with Section
3-33 of this Division. The plaintiff in such suit need not allege or prove
special damage from that suffered by the public at large.
   b.   Any action to declare any act of a governing body null and void, or to
enter an injunction which would invalidate any act of a governing body, based
on violation of this Division occurring before the action is commenced,
including but not limited to provisions on executive sessions and notice, shall
be commenced 1) prior to the delivery of any warrants, notes, bonds, or
obligations if the relief sought would have the effect, if granted, of
invalidating the notes, bonds or obligations, or 2) within thirty (30) days of
the act or failure to act complained of, whichever is sooner.
   c.   In any action filed under this section, a court may award reasonable
attorney fees, court costs, and other reasonable expenses of litigation to the
prevailing party if 1) the plaintiff prevails and the court finds the
defendant's violation is knowing and intentional, or 2) the defendant prevails
and the court finds the action is frivolous and vexatious.
(Ord. No. 885, § 7, 3-10-82)
 
Notes
24 24   I.C., § 5-14-1.5-7, addresses violations, remedies, costs and fees.
Sec. 3-37 through Sec. 3-49 Reserved for Future Use.
Division IV. Miscellaneous Regulations.
Sec. 3-50 Town Membership Authorized.  25
   a.   The Town Council is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the
General Fund or from other funds to provide membership for the Town of
Schererville and the elected and appointed officials and members of the
municipality's boards, council, departments or agencies in local, regional,
state, and national associations of a civic, educational nature, which have as
their purpose the betterment and improvement of municipal operations.
   b.   The Town Council is further authorized to budget and appropriate funds
to pay the expenses of duly authorized representatives to attend the meetings
and functions of organizations to which the municipality belongs.
 
Notes
25 25   I.C., § 36-1-3-2, authorizes powers for the effective operation of
   government
Sec. 3-51 Interlocal Governmental Agreements.
   The Town is authorized pursuant to Indiana Code, §§ 36-1-7-1 through 36-1-7-
12, as it may be amended from time to time, to enter into joint agreements for
the purchase or exchange of property and services with other governmental
bodies through appropriate ordinance or resolution of the Town Council.
Sec. 3-52 Method to Vacate Alleys and Public Ways.  26
   Whenever the Town Council of the Incorporated Town of Schererville, Lake
County, Indiana, shall desire to vacate an alley or alleys or a portion or
portions thereof, within such town, and shall determine that public necessity,
public convenience or public interest require the vacation thereof, it shall
adopt a declaratory resolution to that effect setting forth said desire and
determination to vacate said alley or alleys, or portion or portions thereof,
and vacating the same.
(Ord. No. 342, § 1, 10-17-61)
 
Notes
   26   I.C., § 36-7-3-12, addresses vacating public ways. Editor's Note: Since the
26 codifiers received no further update on this section from the Town Attorney, the
   section remains in its original version.
Sec. 3-53 Purchasing Equipment, Supplies, and Services with Other Communities.
27
   a.   The Town Council of the Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana,
shall take all appropriate and legal measures to enter into the joint
Interlocal Cooperation Agreement with the Towns of Highland, St. John and Dyer,
to purchase and utilize supplies, equipment, and services for the mutual
benefit of the four (4) participating communities, at shared costs.
(Res. No. 94-6, § 1, 2-23-94)
   b.   The President of the Town Council is authorized and permitted to enter
into a Joint Interlocal Cooperation Agreement for the purchase and utilization
of equipment, supplies and services for the mutual benefit of the Towns of
Dyer, Highland, Schererville and St. John, at shared costs, pursuant to the
applicable provisions of I.C. 36-1-7-1, et seq., as amended from time to time;
further, the Town Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to attest the execution of said
agreement by the President of the Town Council.
(Res. No. 94-6, § 2, 2-23-94)

Article 2. Town Court.  28
 
Notes
28 28   I.C., § 33-10.1-1, authorizes the establishment of a Town Court.
Division I. Municipal Judge.  29
 
Notes
29 29   I.C., §§ 3-10-6 or 3-10-7, address the election of a Town Judge.
Sec. 3-70 Town Court Established.
   Under the power vested in it by I.C. § 33-10.1-1-3, the Town Council of
Schererville establishes a Town Court.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 1, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-71 Duration of Town Court.
   The Town Court will come into existence on January 1, 1996 and shall
continue in operation until abolished by ordinance.
(ord. No. 1273, § 2, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-72 Election of Town Court Judge.
   The Judge for the Court shall be elected in the general election held in
November of 1995 and every four (4) years thereafter or as otherwise provided
by Indiana law for the election of municipal judges. The Judge shall be elected
in accordance with I.C., § 3-10-6 by the voters of the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 3, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-73 Qualifications of Town Court Judge.
   To be eligible to hold the office of Town Judge, the Judge must be a
resident of the Town of Schererville during the term of office or the office
becomes vacant. The person selected as Town Judge must be an attorney in good
standing under the requirements of the Supreme Court of Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 4, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-74 Town Judge's Oath and Bond.
   Before beginning the duties of office, the Judge of the Town Court shall
take and subscribe to the same Oath of Office as Judges of the Circuit Courts.
The Judge shall also execute a bond payable to the Town of Schererville in the
penal sum of five-thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful
performance of the duties of the judge's office with good and sufficient
surety. The bond must be approved the Schererville Town Council an d filed in
the Office of the Town Clerk-Treasurer pursuant to Indiana Code § 5-4-1 et seq.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 5, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-75 Court Sessions.
   The Schererville Town Court Judge shall hold sessions of the Town Court as
the business of the court demands at a place to be provided and designated by
the Schererville Town Council.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 6. 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-76 Compensation of Town Court Judge.  30
   The Schererville Town Council shall prescribe compensation for the
Schererville Town Court Judge.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 7, 3-9-94)
 
Notes
   30   Ord. No. 1322A, passed February 14, 1996, established the salaries and
30 wages of the Municipal Judge, Clerks, Bailiff , and Telecom Operators, a copy
   of which is on file in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer and can be viewed by
   the Public during regular business hours.
Sec. 3-77 Style of Court.
   The style of the Town Court is "The Town Court of Schererville".
(Ord. No. 1273, § 8, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-78 Notice to State Court Administration
   The Schererville Town Council shall give Notice of its action to the
Division of State Court Administration of the Office of Judicial Administration
under Indiana Code § 33-2.1-7.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 9, 3-9-94)
Sec. 3-79 Court Procedures.
   The powers, jurisdiction, procedures, practices and administration of the
Court are as provided under I.C. § 33-10.1, et seq., as amended from time to
time.
(Ord. No. 1273, § 10, 39-94).
Sec. 3-80 through Sec. 3-94 Reserved for Future Use.
Division II. Code Violations.
Sec. 3-95 Court Cases.
   The Court costs imposed and applied by the clerk of the Town of
Schererville, Lake County, Indiana for violations of the ordinances of the Town
Code of the Town of Schererville or for infractions of the Town Code of the
Town of Schererville confirm to Indiana Code, § 33-19-5 or as follows:
   a.   A charge of $50.00 for infractions or Town Code Ordinance violations.
   b.   A charge of $3.00 for a law enforcement continuing education program
fee where a defendant in any action is found to have committed a crime,
violated a statute defining an infraction, or violated an ordinance of the Town
of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1055, § 1, 1-13-88; Schererville Town Code, § 1-8-2)
Sec. 3-96 Disbursement.
   Amounts collected by the Clerk or the Court shall be disbursed pursuant to
existing applicable Indiana Code sections. (See the Title 33 Section: 19 of the
Indiana Code)
(Ord. No. 1055, § 2, 1-13-88; Schererville Town Code, § 1-8-2)
Sec. 3-97 Town Attorney to Enforce.  31   
   Unless specific town ordinances or state statutes provide otherwise, or are
in conflict herewith, all ordinances of the Town of Schererville which carry
fines for their violation, and do not provide for or require injunctions,
declaratory judgments or other monetary penalties, shall be enforced by the
Town Attorney, or special prosecuting attorney as designated according to the
procedure set forth in this ordinance, as amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 976, § 1, 3-13-85)
 
Notes
   31   Editor's Note: During the recodification process the Town requested that
31 "or special prosecuting attorney as designated" be added to this Section. See
   also, § 6-235 which addresses the Deferred Prosecution Program.
Sec. 3-98 Ordinance Violation Citation.
   All ordinance violations included within this ordinance shall be filed on a
form entitled "Town Of Schererville Ordinance Violation Citation which shall
state:
   a.   That the Town of Schererville, Indiana, a municipal corporation, is the
Plaintiff;
   b.   The name, address, telephone number, Social Security Number and date of
birth of the Defendant, if known;
   c.   The date and time when the Ordinance violation occurred;
   d.   The specific Ordinance alleged to have been violated by the Defendant;
   e.   The place where the Ordinance violation occurred;
   f.   The manner in which the Ordinance was violated;
   g.   Whether the violation is a single occurrence or a continuing violation.
If the violation is continuing, the date such violation commenced;
   h.   The signature of the complainant, affirming under oath that he has
reasonable and just grounds to believe that the defendant violated the
Ordinance;
   i.   The approval of the Town Attorney or his designate;
   j.   If the violation is a single occurrence, that it is payable and that
the defendant has ten (10) days to pay the designated fine in the Office of the
Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Schererville, and that if the fine is not paid
within said period of time, that the defendant will be cited to appear in
Court.
(Ord. No. 976, § 2, 3-13-85)
Sec. 3-99 Fines.
   Any party who violates any of the provisions of any ordinance of the Town of
Schererville for which another penalty is not specifically provided, and which
is not a continuing violation, commits a payable violation and may pay a fine
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), in the Clerk-Treasurer's Office of the Town of
Schererville within ten (10) days from the date of the citation. In the event
the violation must be enforced through the Lake County Court, a fine of not
less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), nor more than two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00), shall be imposed in addition to Court costs. (See also
Section
1-15 of this Code)
(Ord. No. 976, § 3, 3-13-85)
Sec. 3-100 Non-Payable Violations.
   Any party who violates any of the provisions of any ordinance of the Town of
Schererville for which another penalty is not specifically provided, and which
is a continuing violation, commits a non-payable violation which must be
enforced through the Lake County Court. The fine imposed shall be not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25.00), nor more than two-thousand five-hundred dollars
($2,500.00). Each day that said violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. No. 976, § 4, 3-13-85)
Sec. 3-101 through Sec. 3-109 Reserved for Future Use.
Division III. Prepayment of Ordinance Violations.  32
 
Notes
32 32   Editor's Note: Ord. No. 1346A replaced Ord. No. 1346 which had been
   passed on July 17,1996, and addressed this same topic.
Sec. 3-110 Procedure to Acknowledge Liability - Fines and Court Costs.
   Any individual who is charged with a violation of a town ordinance in the
Town of Schererville, Indiana who wishes to acknowledge liability for aforesaid
violation and pay fine and costs prior to his assigned court date shall be
provided that opportunity by paying a fine of thirty-one dollars and fifty
cents ($31.50) plus court costs of sixty-three dollars and fifty cents
($63.50).
(Ord. No. 1346A, § 1, 8-14-96)
Sec. 3-111 Date When Payments Due.
   Said fine and costs shall be paid to the Clerk of the Court of the Town of
Schererville, Indiana, and must be paid at least five (5) days prior to the
assigned court date.
(Ord. No. 1346A,§ 2, 8-14-96)
Sec. 3-112 Exceptions to Procedures.
   Any individual who violates the following ordinances shall not be provided
the option of prepaying and must appear in court:
   - Speeding in a School Zone;
   - Speed in Excess of Twenty-six (26) Miles per Hour over the Posted Limit;
   - Open Container Violation;
   - Curfew Violation;
   - Vandalism;
   - Nuisance Violation;
   - Zoning Violation;
   - Junk Vehicle;
   - Failure to Obtain a Building Permit;
   - Failure to Obtain a Contractor's License.
(Ord. No. 1346a, § 3, 8-14-96)
Sec. 3-113 through Sec. 3-119 Reserved for Future Use.
Division IV. Community Service Option.
Sec. 3-120 Role of Town Judge.
   The Town Judge for the Town of Schererville, Indiana in passing sentence
upon a finding of guilt or liability related to a violation of Schererville
Town ordinance shall have the discretion to assess community service in lieu of
part or all of any fine imposed.
(Ord. No. 1344, § 1,7-17-96)
Sec. 3-121 Role of Town Court.
   The Town Court shall be responsible for assigning community service provided
that the service take place within the boundaries of Schererville, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1344, § 2, 7-17-96)
Sec. 3-122 Accounting of Community Service Hours.
   The Town Court shall be responsible for accounting for the hours of
community service assigned and shall keep a record of where and when the
community service is performed.
(Ord. No. 1344, § 3, 7-17-96)
Sec. 3-123 through Sec. 3-129 Reserved for Future Use.

Article 1. General Provisions.
Sec. 4-1 Authority to License.  1
   The Town has the authority to impose a license fee that is reasonably
related to the administrative cost of exercising such regulating power.
 
Notes
1    I.C., § 36-1-3-8(5), provides Towns with such licensing power.
Sec. 4-2 Applications.
   All applications for a permit or license under this Chapter shall be made
available by the Town Clerk-Treasurer, unless otherwise specified.
Sec. 4-3 Approval or Disapproval.
   After examination, the Town may grant such permit or license, unless good
cause be shown why said permit or license should not be granted.
Sec. 4-4 Duration of License, Display Required, Inspections.  2
   a.   All licenses issued under this Chapter, unless specified otherwise
shall be issued for the duration of the calendar year for which they were
issued, and shall expire on December 31 st.
   b.   Every person who is issued a license under the provisions of the
licensed activity is being conducted, or if there are no premises shall carry
the license while engaged in the activity for which he has been licensed, and
shall exhibit it to any Town official or citizen upon request.
   c.   The Police Department may inspect all places of business under license
or required to have a license.
 
Notes
2 2   I.C., § 36-8-3-10, authorizes the Police Department to do inspections and set
  forth other duties.
Sec. 4-5 Issuance, Revocation or Suspension.  3
   a.   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue licenses upon payment of the license
fees and compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code.
   b.   Licenses issued by the Town may be revoked or suspended if the person
holding the license has violated the terms or conditions of the license or the
law under which it was issued, or has conducted the business in such a manner
as to constitute a threat to public health, safety, or the general welfare of
the Town citizens.
 
Notes
3 3   I.C., § 36-1-3-10, authorizes the Clerk-Treasurer to issue licenses.
Sec. 4-6 through Sec. 4-9 Reserved for Future Use.
ARTICLE 2. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES REGULATED.
Division I. Motorized Bicycles.  4
 
Notes
4 4   I.C., § 9-13-2-109, defines "motorized bicycle".
Sec. 4-10 Definitions.
   The following definitions shall be applicable for purposes of this division.
   a.   Motorized bicycle - A bicycle with operable petals which may be
propelled by human power or by an internal combustion engine or a battery
powered motor, or by both, and when powered by an internal combustion engine
having a rating of no more than two (2) (2.0) brake horsepower and a cylinder
capacity not exceeding fifty (50) cubic centimeters, and automatic
transmission, and a maximum design speed of no more than twenty-five (25) miles
per hour on a flat surface.
   b.   Owner - A person who holds the legal title of a motorized bicycle or
any person renting or leasing a motorized bicycle and having exclusive use
thereof for period longer than thirty (30) days, or in the event a motorized
bicycle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional vendee or lessee, or
in the event the mortgagor thereof, with the right of purchase upon the
performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate
right of possession of a motorized bicycle is entitled to possession, then such
conditional vendee or mortgagor shall be deemed to be the owner for the purpose
of this division.
   c.   Operate - The word "operate" or any form or tense thereof shall mean to
ride in or on, to drive, to use, to put into action, cause to function, or to
be in actual physical control of a motorized bicycle as defined herein.
   d.   Persons - Every natural person, firm, co-partnership or corporation or
association.
   e.   Pedestrian - Any person afoot.
   f.   Operator - Any person who drives, operates, or is in actual physical
control of a bicycle or vehicle defined herein.
   g.   Vehicle - Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is
or may be transported or drawn upon a roadway or highway, except devices moved
by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
(Ord. No. 1098, § 1, 3-8-89; Schererville Town Code, § 8-10-1)
Sec. 4-11 Registration and Licensing Required.
   a.   The provisions of this division shall apply whenever a motorized
bicycle is operated in the Town of Schererville, subject to those exceptions
stated herein.
   b.   Every motorized bicycle, either owned by a resident of the Town of
Schererville or stored within the Town of Schererville (excepting motorized
bicycles held primarily for resale in the ordinary course of business) shall be
registered and licensed with the Police Department of the Town of Schererville.
   c.   Every person who owns or store a motorized bicycle within the Town of
Schererville on the effective date of this ordinance or thereafter shall
register and license his or her motorized bicycle within thirty (30) days
following said effective date. Thereafter, every person subject to this
division shall register his or her motorized bicycle and obtain a license
within fifteen (15) days after becoming the owner, as defined herein, of the
said motorized bicycle or commencing the storage of the said motorized bicycle.
The license shall expire two (2) years following the date the license was
issued. Each motorized bicycle shall be re-registered and re-licensed not less
than thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the license.
(Ord. No. 1098, § 2, 3-8-89; Schererville Town Code, § 8-10-2)
   d.   Licensing of Motorized Vehicles - Any person fifteen (15) years of age
or older owning a motorized bicycle shall obtain a license for each motorized
bicycle from the Schererville Police Department. No license shall be issued to,
or for the benefit of any person under the age of fifteen (15) years, owning a
motorized bicycle.
   The license issued for a motorized bicycle is not transferable
   Each person filing an application for registration and issuance of a license
for a motorized bicycle shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each
motorized bicycle so registered and licensed. The funds paid for said
registration shall be placed in an account for the purchase or repair of
equipment for the police department maintained for that purpose by the Clerk-
Treasurer.
   The Schererville Police Department shall set specific times regarding the
issuance of licenses and said times shall be posted at the Schererville Police
Department. No licenses shall be issued at any times, but those designated by
the department.
(Ord. No. 1098, § 2, 3-8-89; Schererville Town Code, § 8-10-3)
Sec. 4-12 Rules and Regulations.
   a.   Minimum Age of Operator   5  - A motorized bicycle shall not be
operated by any person under the age of fifteen (15) years of age, without an
identification card issued pursuant to Indiana Code, § 9-24-16-1, et seq. or a
valid driver's license issued pursuant to Indiana Code, § 9-13-2, et seq. Each
operator shall carry on his or her person sufficient evidence of his or her
age.
   b.   Obedience to Traffic Control Devices - Operators of motorized bicycles
shall obey the direction and instruction of all traffic control devices,
signals, signs, or other control devices applicable to vehicles, as defined in
and subject to the rules and regulations of the Indiana Code.
   c.   Obedience to Traffic Control Signs - Whenever authorized signs are
erected, including, but not limited to stop, yield, no right or left or "U"
turns, no person operating a motorized bicycle shall disobey the purpose and
direction of any such sign, except where such operator dismounts from the
motorized bicycle and obeys the regulation as defined in the Indiana Code
applicable to pedestrians.
   d.   Use of Seats; Maximum Capacity - A person operating a motorized bicycle
shall not drive it other than upon the permanent and regular seat attached
thereto, nor shall the operator permit a passenger. If a passenger is allowed,
the motorized vehicle shall be equipped with fixed foot pegs or pedals for the
use of said passenger.
   e.   Speed - No person shall operate a motorized bicycle at a speed greater
than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. The operator
of a motorized bicycle shall not exceed the speed of twenty-five (25) miler per
hour or the posted speed limit, whichever is less.
   f.   Driving on the Right; Riding Abreast Restricted - Every person
operating a motorized bicycle shall drive as near to the right hand side of the
roadway as is possible, and in single file when passing other vehicles, parked
or moving.
   g.   Merging from Alley or Driveway - The operator of a motorized bicycle
emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall, upon approaching a
sidewalk, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on said
sidewalk or sidewalk area and upon entering a roadway, shall yield the right-
of-way to all vehicles on the roadway close enough to constitute a hazard.
   h.   Clinging to Vehicles - No person operating a motorized bicycle shall
attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a public highway, street, alley,
public way, park way or public path.
   i.   Carrying Articles - No person operating a motorized bicycle shall carry
any package, bundle, or article which prevents the operator from keeping both
hands upon the handlebars.
   j.   Trick Riding - Trick riding is prohibited. The hands of the operator of
a motorized vehicle shall be on the handlebars at all times, except while in
the act of signaling.
   k.   Curving Side to Side - No operator of a motorized bicycle shall cause
or permit a motorized bicycle to curve side to side.
   1.   Parking - No person shall park a motorized bicycle in such a manner as
to interfere with the normal flow of pedestrian traffic, vehicular parking or
vehicular flow of traffic.
   m.   Operation on Sidewalk Prohibited - The operation of motorized bicycles
upon sidewalks is expressly prohibited.
   n.   Lights - Every motorized bicycle, operated on a public highway, street,
alley, public way or public path, shall be equipped with a lamp on the front
exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet
(500') to the front and with a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red tight visible
from a distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear. In lieu of such rear
lighted red lamp on motorized bicycles, a red reflector glass button no less
than one and one-half inches (1½") in diameter, or red reflecting tape of not
less than four square inches (4") may be mounted securely on the rear mudguard,
or lacing a mudguard on the rear of the saddle. The tights are to be on at all
times the motorized bicycle is in use.
   o.   Audible Warning Devices - No person shall ride a motorized bicycle
unless it is equipped with horn or other device capable of giving a signal
audible for a distance of one hundred feet (100') or more.
   p.   Brakes - Every motorized bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which
will enable the operator to make the braked wheels skid on dry, level, or clean
pavement.
   q.   Turning Signals - Every person operating a motorized bicycle shall
employ the use of hand signals in the manner provided by state law for turning
or changing lanes if such vehicle is not equipped with a lighted turn signal
device.
   r.   Protective Headgear - A person who operates a motorized bicycle within
the Town of Schererville shall at all times wear protective headgear meeting
the minimum standards set by the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles or a helmet
that meets the standards established by the United States Department of
Transportation under 4a CFR 571-218 and in effect as of January 1,1979, or as
amended or replaced thereafter.
   s.   Protective Glasses, Goggles, or a Transparent Face Shield - A person
who operates a motorized bicycle within the Town of Schererville shall at all
times wear protective glasses, goggles, or transparent face shield.
   t.   Motorized Bicycle Traffic Prohibited on Highways U.S. 30 and U.S. 41
Within the Town of Schererville - The operation of a motorized bicycle is
expressly prohibited on the roadway or shoulder areas of Highways U.S. 30 or
U.S. 41 within the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1098, § 3, 3-8-89; Schererville Town Code, § 8-10-3)
 
Notes
  5   Editor's Note: At the time Ord. No. 1098 was passed, it referred to I.C., §§
5 9-4-1 and 9-5-3.1, et seq., which have been repealed. The section references
  current state law.
Sec. 4-13 Penalties.
   a.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this Division relating to
motorized bicycles shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each offense. The parent or guardian of any person under
the age of fifteen (15) years old violating any provision herein shall be
deemed to have violated this ordinance. It is the duty and obligation of every
parent or guardian to ensure that the provisions herein are adhered to by those
persons under the age of fifteen (15) years.
   b.   Should a party violate the provisions of this Division the Schererville
Police Department may impound the vehicle and if the operator of an impounded
vehicle is a minor, said motorized bicycle will only be released to the minor
child's parents or legal guardians.
(Ord. No. 1098, § 4, 3-8-89; Schererville Town Code, § 8-10-4)
Sec. 4-14 through Sec. 4-17 Reserved for Future Use.
Division II. Registration of All Electronic or Video Type Entertainment
Machines or Games, and Cigarette Dispensing Machines.
Sec. 4-18 Definitions.
   The following definitions shall apply to this Division:
   a.   Video Game - Any device that provides entertainment in exchange for the
payment of money by the player or players, whether said device operates or
projects an image on a video screen or not.
   b.   Electronic Game - Any device that provides entertainment in exchange
for the payment of money by the player or players. An example is a pin ball
machine.
   c.   Cigarette Dispensing Machine - Any device which dispenses cigarettes in
exchange of the payment of money.
   d.   Commercial Establishment - Any building or part of a building used for
any commercial or business purpose whether for profit or not-for-profit. These
include, but are not limited to - stores, arcades, restaurants, service
stations, taverns, social clubs, private clubs, shopping centers, malls,
religious or charitable organization establishments.
   e.   Owner - A persons corporation, partnership, association or entity who
hold title or right of possession to any video game, electronic game, cigarette
dispensing machine, or any building, establishment or real estate upon which a
building is located, or a commercial establishment within a building.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 1, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-1)
Sec. 4-19 Record of Registration and Stickers Registration.
   a.   The Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Schererville shall cause to be
printed or produced registration stickers, or emblems, with consecutive numbers
printed upon them. As each machine or device is registered and the required
registration fee paid, a sticker shall be issued to the person or entity paying
the fee. The registrant shall complete or cause to be completed a questionnaire
form disclosing the following information:
      1.   Name of owner of commercial establishment in which the device or
machine is located
      2.   Business name of the establishment.
      3.   Address of said establishment.
      4.   Owner of the real estate in which said establishment is located.
      5.   Address of the owner of the real estate.
      6.   Type of device or machine or game.
      7.   Name of the game or machine or device.
      8.   Name of the owner of said game or machine or device.
      9.   Address of said owner.
      10.   Serial number of the game, device, or machine.
      11.   Date when said machine, game or device was placed into service at
this particular location.
      12.   Any other information which the Clerk-Treasurer or Police
Department of the Town may require or deem necessary.
   b.   A copy of this record of registration shall be maintained by the Clerk-
Treasurer and one copy sent to the Police Department.
   c.   These records of registration are public records.
   d.   Each sticker or emblem shall be assigned to one machine, game or device
and a record kept by the Clerk-Treasurer and Police Department showing which
number of each sticker or emblem is assigned to which machine, game or device.
   e.   This sticker or emblem shall be prominently displayed upon the game,
device or machine to which it is assigned.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 2, 9-14-88, Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-2)
Sec. 4-20 Rotation of Machines.
   a.   The Town recognizes that some devices or games may be rotated from time
to time by the owner of any device or game. No new registration fee is required
if any such game or device is moved from one location in Schererville to
another location in Schererville,
   b.   The owner shall be required to notify the Clerk-Treasurer of the
rotation of any machine, device or game within the town, into the town or out
of the town within ten (10) days of their rotation or movement.
   c.   A registration fee paid on any machine or device shall not be refunded
should any machine or device be removed prior to the expiration of the term of
registration.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 3, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-3)
Sec. 4-21 Registration Fees.
   a.   The registration fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the
registration of each video game, electronic game or cigarette machine per year.
   b.   The term of registration shall be one year commencing January 1, 1989
and beginning each successive first day of January each year thereafter and
commencing on December 31 of each year.
   c.   Said registration fee shall be paid on or before February 1 of each
year.
   d.   Any machine, game or device brought into the town or placed into
service prior to July 1 of any year shall pay the full one hundred dollar
($100.00) registration fee.
   e.   Any machine or device or game brought into the town or placed into
service after July 1 of any year shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00) as
registration fee for the remainder of that registration period only.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 4, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-4)
Sec. 4-22 Temporary Registration.
   a.   Any said machines used on a temporary basis or seven (7) consecutive
days or less for purposes of fairs, carnivals, fund raising events,
entertainment events or the like shall also be registered as temporary machines
in accordance with the terms of this Division.
   b.   The fee for temporary registration shall be twenty-five dollars
($25.00) per week or five dollars ($5.00) per day.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 5, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-5)
Sec. 4-23 Inspections.
   a.   The Schererville Police Department shall be required to inspect and
supervise this registration. The Police Department shall make periodic
inspections of all commercial establishments within the town and inspect all
such devices, games and machines and ensure they are properly operating for the
protection of the public.
   b.   Any device, machine or game not registered shall be promptly reported
to the Clerk-Treasurer and the Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 6, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-6)
Sec. 4-24 Violations and Penalties.
   a.   Failure to register any device, game or machine required to be
registered under the terms of this Division shall be considered a violation.
   b.   Any violation reported to or discovered by the Police Department or any
other representative or employee of the Town of Schererville shall be processed
as follows:
      1.   A written notice of failure to register shall be mailed or delivered
to the owner or operator of the commercial establishment in which said device,
game or machine is located allowing a ten (10) day period from the date of the
notice to pay the full one year registration fee regardless whether it occurs
prior or after July 1 of any year.
      2.   If the ten (10) day grace period passes and the registration fee is
still not paid, a second notice shall be mailed or delivered to the owner or
operator of the commercial establishment in which said game or device or
machine is located requiring its immediate removal or payment of double the
annual registration fee within five (5) days of the notice.
      3.   Failure to remove the game, machine or device or failure to pay the
double registration fee shall result in a civil penalty of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) assessed against the owner of the machine, device or game,
the owner of the real estate in which the commercial establishment is located
or the owner of the commercial establishment in which the machine, game or
device is located or all of the above jointly or singularly. Should the town be
required to enforce this penalty in Court, the above named persons or entities
shall also be liable for court costs and attorney fees for enforcement which
attorneys fees shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   c.   The civil penalty shall be applicable even though the machine, device
or game was eventually removed from the premises during or after the five (5)
day notice period.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 7, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-7)
Sec. 4-25 Monies Collected by Clerk-Treasurer.
   a.   All proceeds from registration fees, penalties or fines thereon shall
be placed in a separate account to be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   b.   All funds or fines collected by the Clerk-Treasurer shall be divided as
follows:
      1.   Twenty-five percent (25%) shall be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer
to defray the costs of printing stickers, creating and maintaining files and
other general clerical expenses and other expenses for supplies and overhead.
      2.   Seventy-five percent (75%) shall be deposited in a separate fund
created and maintained for the sole purpose of purchasing or maintaining
equipment for the Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1084, § 8, 9-14-88; Schererville Town Code, § 5-4-8)
Sec. 4-26 Maximum Registration Fee.
   a.   The Town Council establishes that there shall exist a maximum
registration fee for any and all video games which are operated out of the same
address in the Town of Schererville, Indiana, and that said maximum fee shall
be two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)
   b.   Any business owner who has in excess of twenty-five (25) machines at a
single location shall not be assessed any registration cost above and beyond
two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
   c.   It is the intent of the Town Council that this ordinance take affect
for the calendar year 1999 and that its application shall be intended to be
retroactive to January 1, 1999.
   d.   Should any business owner already have registered his machines and aid
in excess of two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) minimum fee, then
the Town of Schererville, Indiana, shall refund any excess portion to the
business owner.
(Ord. No. 1084A, § § 1-4, 4-14-99)
Sec. 4-27 through Sec. 4-29 Reserved for Future Use.
Division III. Licensing Businesses, Business Activities, Occupations, and
Commercial Establishments.
Sec. 4-30 License Required.
   All persons and parties, of whatever nature, engaged in the maintenance,
operation and conduct of any business, business activity, occupation or
commercial establishment, shall be required to first obtain a license for such
business from the Town of Schererville. The requirement to obtain a business
license shall include any individual person, party, partner or corporate
entity, as well as their agents, employees, and representatives presenting
themselves as engaged in the business or soliciting patronage therefore,
actively or passively, or performing or attempting to perform any part of such
business within the Town.
(Ord. No. 1 31, § 1, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-1)
Sec. 4-31 Applications.
   Applications for all business licenses required by this Division shall be
made in writing to the Town Clerk-Treasurer. Each application shall state the
name of the applicant, the business name, the nature of the business, the
location of the business, the fee to be paid, the time period for such license,
and all other information deemed appropriate and necessary by the Town for
review in the consideration of issuance of the business license. Additionally,
each business located within the boundaries of the Town, upon being licensed or
obtaining any renewal thereof, shall provide as part of its business
application a Recycling Plan, on a Town provided form, describing how its solid
waste will be managed, including reduction, reuse and recycling steps taken to
reduce its solid waste stream, which plan shall be subject to approval as
provided in this Division.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 2, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-2; Ord. No. 1649, §
1, 7-13-05)
Sec. 4-32 Role of Clerk-Treasurer.
   All forms for business licenses required by this Division, including
applications, shall be maintained and held in the Office of the Town Clerk-
Treasurer.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 3, 6-10-87, Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-3)
Sec. 4-33 Investigations.
   Upon receipt of an application for a business license required by this
Division, the Town Clerk-Treasurer shall refer the application to the Town
Official duly designated and appointed by the Town Council for such purpose.
The duly designated Town Official shall, upon receipt of an application,
investigate the matters contained on said application, and prepare a report and
recommendation. The Town Official investigating applications shall have the
authority to review said application and related matters with all other
appropriate and necessary Town Officials, including, but not limited to,
Inspectors, Health Officials, and the like.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 4, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-4)
Sec. 4-34 Non-Refundable License Fee.
   Any person or party, of whatever nature, engaged in the maintenance,
operation or conduct of any business, business activity, occupation or
commercial establishment, within the Town shall pay a bi-annual non-refundable
license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event any person or party becomes
engaged in the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business, business
activity, occupation or commercial establishment within the Town prior to June
30th of any calendar year, that person or party shall be required to comply
with the provisions, regarding fee paid, of this ordinance, as amended from
time to time. In the event any person or party becomes engaged in the
maintenance, operation or conduct of any business, business activity,
occupation or commercial establishment within the Town after June 30th of any
calendar year, then that person or party shall be entitled to a one-half (½)
reduction of the license fee owed. The reduction shall be based upon the bi-
annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). The reduction of fee owed shall be for
that partial calendar year only. The license issued for the partial calendar
year shall terminate on the last day of the calendar year, and thereafter, the
person or party engaged in the maintenance operation or conduct of any
business, business activity, occupation or commercial establishment within the
Town shall be required to comply with the provisions of this Division, as
amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 1031 A, 8-12-87; Schererville Town Code; § 5-1-5)
Sec. 4-35 Fees Paid to Clerk-Treasurer.
   All fees for the licensing of a business within the Town shall be paid in
advance at the time application therefore is made to the Town Clerk-Treasurer.
All business license fees collected pursuant to this Division shall be paid
into the General Fund of the Town.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 6, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code; § 5-1-6)
Sec. 4-36 Validity and Termination.
   a.   All business licenses shall be valid for a two (2) year period,
commencing on January 1st of any given year, except as provided for partial
time periods of a year in Section
4-34 as amended from time to time. All business licenses shall terminate on the
last day of the second calendar year, after issuance and validity, except as
provided in Section
4-34.
   b.   The Town Clerk-Treasurer shall mail to all business licensees within
the Town a notice and statement of expiration and renewal three (3) weeks prior
to the expiration of the license at the end of a calendar year. A failure to
mail such notice and statement or failure of a business licensee to receive
such notice shall not excuse the business licensee from a failure to obtain a
new license or renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in an action for
operation without a license.
(Ord. No. 1031 A, 8-12-87; Schererville Town Code; § 5-1-7)
Sec. 4-37 Compliance Required.
   No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business or business
activity if the premises and building to be used for the business purpose do
not fully comply with all other requirements and ordinances of the Town.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 8, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-8)
Sec. 4-38 Reasons Not to Issue License.
   No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of
any act which is in violation or which would involve a violation of any
ordinance of the Town, or any law, rule, statute or regulation of the State of
Indiana or the United States.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 9, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-9)
Sec. 4-39 Change of Location.
   The location of any business or occupation for which a business license has
been issued may be changed, on the condition that ten (10) days' prior notice
thereof is given to the Town Clerk-Treasurer and the new location meets all of
the requirements for the issuance of the original license.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 10,6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-10)
Sec. 4-40 Inspections.
   Whenever inspection is required by the duly designated Town Official
investigating the application for a business license, the duly designated Town
Official shall be permitted to inspect the premises where the business would be
conducted, at any reasonable time. A licensee shall be required to permit
inspection of the business premises by the duly designated Town Official after
issuance of the business license, at any reasonable time, to ensure conformance
with the provisions of this ordinance and all other applicable Town
requirements and ordinances.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 11, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-11)
Sec. 4-41 Reasons for Suspension.
   Any business license issued by the Town may be suspended or revoked by the
Town Council for any one (1) or more of the following reasons:
   a.   Violation by the licensee of a Town requirement or ordinance;
   b.   Violation by the licensee of any rule, law, statute or regulation of
the State of Indiana or of the United States, or any department or division
thereof;
   c.   Misrepresentation or falsification of statements in the application for
license, or renewal thereof;
   d.   Any cause deemed just, but which cause shall not be unreasonable,
arbitrary or capricious
(Ord. No. 1031A, 8-12-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-12)
Sec. 4-42 Hearings, Revocations and Suspensions.
   a.   In the event of violation of this Division as described in Section
4-40, an investigation shall be conducted by the duly designated Town Official
regarding such violation. If the violation is one which the duly designated
Town Official has reason to believe may be corrected, written notice shall be
served upon the licensee setting forth the violations. Upon receipt of the
notice of violations, the licensee shall have not less than five (5) days nor
more than thirty (30) days, as set by the duly designated Town Official, to
correct the violation and submit evidence of the correction to the Town.
   b.   In the event that corrections of license violations are not made as
required, or the violation is one which the duly designated Town Official has
reason to believe is unable to be corrected, the Town may suspend or revoke any
business license issued for violation described in Section
4-40, provided, however, that a business licensee shall have the right to a
hearing. Before the suspension or revocation of any business license, the duly
designated Town Official shall give written notice to the licensee of the
violation or violations and set forth a date for hearing for the purpose of
suspending or revoking such license or permit. The revocation or suspension
hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) days after the service of written
notice upon the licensee. However, in the event a determination is made that
immediate and irreparable harm or damage to person or property may occur by
reason of the violation or violations, the hearing may be held after twenty-
four (24) hours following the service of the written notice upon the licensee.
   c.   A suspension or revocation of a business license shall be supplementary
to any other remedies available to the Town and shall not stay any other
enforcement proceedings of the Town.
   d.   Any business licensee whose license has been revoked shall not have the
right to re-apply for a license until the calendar year beginning after the
year in which the specific business license has been revoked. The Town Council
may deny a business license to any applicant who has had a license issued by
the Town revoked.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 13, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-14)
Sec. 4-43 Display of License Required.
   A business licensee shall be required to place his license in a prominent
place on the premises used for such business or activity at all times.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 14, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-15)
Sec. 4-44 Operating Without a License.
   The maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or business activity
in the Town of Schererville without a license, as required by this Division,
shall be deemed to be in violation of this Division.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 15, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-16)
Sec. 4-45 Penalties.
   Any person, party, firm or corporation which violates any of the provisions
of this Division shall be subject to a fine in an amount not less than twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) and not more than two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) for each offense. Each day of the existence of any violation of
this Ordinance shall be deemed a separate offense. The remedy provided herein
shall be cumulative and not exclusive and shall be in addition to any other
remedies provided by law, including, but not limited to, injunction.
(Ord. No. 1031, § 16, 6-10-87; Schererville Town Code, § 5-1-17)
Sec. 4-46 through Sec. 4-49 Reserved for Future Use.
Division IV. Massage Establishments. Masseurs and Masseuses.
Sec. 4-50 Short Title.
   This Division shall be known and may be cited as the "Massage Parlor
Ordinance of the Town of Schererville, Indiana".
(Ord. No. 623, § 1, 11-13-74; Schererville Town Code, § 5-6-1)
Sec. 4-51 Policy.
   It is declared that the business of operating massage establishments as
defined herein is a business affecting the public health, safety and general
welfare.
(Ord. No. 623, § 2, 11-13-74; Schererville Town Code, § 5-6-2)
Sec. 4-52 Definitions.
   For the purpose of this Division, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   a.   Massage - Any method of pressure on or friction against, or stroking,
kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating of the external
soft parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or
electrical apparatus or appliance with or without such supplementary aids as
rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder, lotions, ointments or
other similar preparations commonly used in this practice.
   b.   Massage establishment - Any establishment having a fixed place or
business where any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or
carried on or permits to be engaged in or carried on any of the activities
mentioned in Section
4-52 of this Division.
   c.   Masseur or masseuse - Any person who, for any consideration whatsoever,
engages in the practice of massage as herein defined.
   d.   Employee - Any and all persons, other than the masseurs or masseuses,
who render any service to the permittee, who receive compensation directly from
the permittee, and who have no physical contact with customers and clients.
   e.   Person - Any individual, copartnership, firm, association, joint stock
company, corporation or combination of individuals of whatever form or
character.
(Ord. No. 623, § 3, 11-13-74; Schererville Town Code, § 5-6-3)
Sec. 4-53 Permit Required.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on or to
permit to be engaged in, conducted or earned on, in or upon any premises in the
Town of Schererville, Indiana, the operation of a massage establishment as
herein defined, without first having obtained a license as hereinafter
provided.
(Ord. No. 623, § 4, 11-13-74; Schererville Town Code, § 5-6-4)
Sec. 4-54 Application.
   Application for such licenses shall be made to the Clerk-Treasurer of the
Town of Schererville, Indiana, in writing signed by the applicant, if an
individual, if a partnership by all partners, if a corporation by a duly
authorized agent, verified by oath or affidavit and shall contain the following
statements and information:
   a.   The name, age and home address, occupation and social security number
of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a partnership,
the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; in the case of a
corporation, all officers and directors and if a majority interest of the stock
of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, then such person
shall be included.
   If a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation approved by the
Secretary of State shall be attached.
   b.   Business address of the proposed location of applicant's business.
   c.   Name and home address of owner of the real property of proposed
location of applicant's business.
   d.   a statement as to whether applicant had made application for any
license issued by the Town of Schererville, Indiana, and the disposition of
such other applications.
   e.   a statement as to whether any previous license issued to the applicant
by the state or subdivision thereof or by any federal agency or department has
been revoked or suspended and the reasons therefore.
   f.   a statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime
or misdemeanor, if an individual; in the case of a partnership, the persons
entitled to share in the profits thereof; the case of a corporation, all
officers and directors and if a majority interest of the stock of such
corporation is owned by one person, or his nominee, then such person shall be
included. Such statement shall include the nature of the offense, date of
conviction, court where convicted, and punishment of penalty assessed therefor.
   g.   If the business is to be managed by anyone other than an individual
applicant, then the applicant shall state the name and home address, social
security number, present occupation and a statement of any convictions of any
crime or misdemeanor including the nature of the offense and date of
conviction, court where convicted, and punishment or penalty assessed therefor
of any person or persons who will manage or operate said business.
   h.   The fingerprints of the applicant, if an individual; in the case of a
partnership, all persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; in the case
of a corporation, all officers and directors, and if a majority interest of the
stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, then such
person shall be included.
   In the event a manager is employed then said manager shall be included. The
finger-prints shall be taken by the Town Police Department.
   i.   a description of the premises of the proposed location indicating the
dimensions of all rooms, the location of the tables, the location of exits and
such other information as may be requested by the Clerk-Treasurer in order to
determine whether the premises complies with all applicable laws.
   j.   The names of at least two (2) reliable real property owners of Lake
County who will certify as to the good character and business respectability of
the applicant, if an individual; in the case of a partnership, all persons
entitled to share in the profits thereof; in the case of a corporation, all
officers and directors, and if a majority interest of the stock of such
corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, then such person shall be
included. In the event the applicant cannot provide such names then, in lieu
thereof, such applicant shall state the reasons for noncompliance and may then
