provide such other available evidence that may be requested by the Clerk-
Treasurer to show the good character and business responsibility of the
applicant.
   k.   Two (2) portraits at least 2 inches by 2 inches in size.
   1.   The massage or similar business license history of the applicant;
whether such person, in previously operating in this or another city or state
under license, has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor,
and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension
or revocation.
(Ord. No. 623, § 5, 11-13-74; Schererville Town Code, § 5-6-5)
Sec. 4-55 Masseur or Masseuse Permit.
   Any person, including an applicant for a massage establishment license, who
engages in the practice of massage as herein defined shall file an application
for a masseur or masseuse license with the Clerk-Treasurer upon a form provided
and shall pay a riling fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) which shall not be
refundable.
(Ord. No. 623, § 6, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-56 Investigations.
   a.   Upon receipt of a completed application, as hereinabove prescribed,
together with the stated fee, the Clerk-Treasurer shall refer the same to the
Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners of the Town who shall cause the
matters stated in the application, as well as the applicants, to be
investigated by the Police Department of the Town. At the conclusion of such
investigation, the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners shall make a
report to Town Council of the Town, which shall be confidential in nature and
which, together with the application, shall be considered by the Board in
determining whether or not to grant the application and issue the license
applied for.
   b.   If the Town Council determines the application to be in order, and upon
receipt of a favorable report from the Police Commission, then the Town Council
of the Town shall authorize the Clerk-Treasurer to issue the license applied
for. If, on the other hand, the application is defective, or the report of the
Police Commission is adverse or tends to indicate that the information in the
application is not viable, or is defective then, and in that event, the Town
Council of the Town shall instruct the Clerk-Treasurer not to issue the license
and to notify the applicant accordingly of the Council's action.
(Ord. No. 623, § 7, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-57 Regulations.
   The holder of any license issued pursuant to this Division shall at all
times comply with the following requirements:
   a.   Minors under the age of eighteen years shall under no circumstances
frequent, loiter, go or remain in any massage establishment licensed hereunder
at any time, unless it be upon some lawful errand and sent under the direction,
and the consent and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having
the lawful custody of such minor; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor
of any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter
or remain within the hall in violation of this section.
   b.   No massage establishment shall be operated, maintained or conducted in
such a manner as to constitute a common nuisance.
   c.   No license issued pursuant to this Division shall be transferred to any
other person, partnership or corporation.
   d.   All licenses issued pursuant to this Division shall be conspicuously
posted in the licensed premises.
   e.   All massage establishments shall be open for inspection by authorized
city officers and employees during normal business hours.
   f.   Every portion of a massage establishment including appliances,
apparatus, and personnel shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary
condition.
   g.   All employees shall be clean and wear clean outer garments whose use is
restricted to the massage establishment. Provisions for a separate dressing
room for each sex must be available on the premises with individual lockers for
each employee. Doors to such dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be
self-closing.
   h.   All employees, masseurs, and masseuses must be modestly attired.
Diaphanous, flimsy, transparent, form-fitting, or tight clothing is prohibited.
Clothing must cover the employees', masseurs' or masseuses' chests at all
times. Hemlines of skirts, dresses, or other such attire must be no higher than
the top of the knee.
   i.   The private parts of patrons must be covered by towels, cloths, or
undergarments when in the presence of an employee, masseur or masseuse. Any
contact with a patron's genital area is strictly prohibited.
   j.   All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered
sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
thereof and stored in approved, sanitary manner.
   k.   Wet and dry heat rooms, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be
thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be
thoroughly cleaned after each use.
   l.   Advertising. No massage establishment granted a permit under provisions
of this Division shall place publish or distribute or cause to be placed,
published or distributed any advertising matter that depicts any portion of the
human body that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any
service is available other than those services as described in Section
4-52 or that employees, masseurs, or masseuses, are dressed in any manner other
than described in Sec. 4-52 (3) nor shall any massage establishment indicate in
the text of such advertising that any service is available other than those
services described in Section
4-52.
   m.   All services enumerated in Section
4-52 must be carried on in one cubicle, room, booth, or area within the massage
establishment. No service enumerated in Section
4-52 may be carried on in any other cubicle, room, booth or area except where
such cubicle, room, booth, or area has transparent doors or walls, such that
all activity within the cubicle, room, booth or area is visible from outside
the same.
   n.   A massage establishment shall not carry on, engage in, or conduct
business on Sunday and on other days shall not carry on, engage in, or conduct
business before 8:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m.
(Ord. No. 623, § 8, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-58 Daily Register.
   Every person who engages in or conducts a massage establishment shall keep a
daily register, approved as to form by the Police Department, of all patrons,
with names, addresses and hours of arrival and, if applicable, the rooms or
cubicles assigned. Said daily register shall at all times during business hours
be subject to inspection by Health Department officials and by the Police
Department and shall be kept on file for one (1) year.
(Ord. No. 623, § 9, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-59 Exemptions.
   This Division shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes, sanitaria, or
persons holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the healing arts under the
laws of the State of Indiana or to persons working under the direction of any
such person or in any such establishments.
(Ord. No. 623, § 10, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-60 Fees.
   The annual fee for such licenses shall be as follows:
   a.   Massage Establishment   $50.00
   b.   Masseur, Masseuse      $25.00
(Ord. No. 623, § 11, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-61 Violation and Penalty.
   Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by this
Division, whether acting as an individual, owner, employee of the owner,
operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting as a mere helper for
the owner, employee or operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any
way, who gives massages or conducts a massage establishment without first
obtaining a permit and paying a license fee to do so from the Town of
Schererville, Indiana, or shall violate any of the provisions of this Division
shall be guilty of an ordinance violation. Upon being found in violation, such
person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 623, § 12, 11-13-74)
Sec. 4-62 through Sec. 4-64 Reserved for Future Use.
Division V. Alarm Systems.
Sec. 4-65 Definitions.
   The following words, terms and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to
them in this section for the purposes of this Division:
   a.   Alarm Equipment Supplier - Any person that sells, leases, installs or
otherwise deals in automatic protection devices or signaling devices which
transmit alarms upon a stimulus from a detection apparatus or a manually
operated system.
   b.   Alarm Conditions - Alarms activated by unlawful violation of a user's
property, other violations that the systems were designed to protect against,
acts of God, other violent conditions, outside agencies, hazards or external
forces not under the control of the owner, lessee or his employee or agent.
(Ord. No. 977, § 1, A, B, 4-10-85)
   c.   Alarm User - Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained
within the Town of Schererville, including those systems which employ an
audible signal emitting sounds or a flashing light or beacon designed to alert
or signal persons outside the premises.
(Ord. No. 13 85-A, § 1,7-9-97)
   d.   Alarm System - An assembly of equipment and devices, such as a solid
state unit, arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent
attention and to which the Police or Fire Departments are expected to respond.
   e.   Central Station - A facility whose prime purpose is to monitor incoming
alarm signals twenty-four (24) hours a day and relay the signal information to
the appropriate authorities.
   f.   Direct Line - A telephone line leading directly into the communications
center of the Police Department that is for use only to report signals on a
station-to-station basis.
(Ord. No, 977, § 1, D, E, F, 4-10-85)
   g.   False Alarms - The activation of an alarm system caused by improper
operation, negligence of the owner of lessee or his employee or agent, or
equipment malfunction.
(Ord. No. 1385-A, § 1, 7-9-97)
   h.   Local Alarms - A signaling system which, when activated, causes an
audible and/or visual signaling device to be activated in or on the premises
within which the system is installed.
   i.   Person - Any individual, partnership, corporation, association, or
society, but such term does not include the Town of Schererville.
   j.   Police Chief or Chief of Police - The Chief of the Police Department of
the Town of Schererville or his authorized representative.
(Ord. No. 1385-A, § 1, 7-9-97)
   k.   Public Trunkline - A telephone line leading into the communications
center of the Police Department that is for the purpose of handling emergency
and administrative calls on a person-to-person basis.
   l.   Signaling Device - An electrically operated instrument which
automatically sends visual and/or audible signals to be registered by
indicators at a monitor panel at the receiving terminal or central station.
   m.   Signal Board - A system located in the Police Department to receive
visual and audible signals over direct lines to note a fire, burglary or other
emergency at specific locations within the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 977, § 1H, I, J, K, L, M, 4-10-85)
   n.   Town - Town of Schererville, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1385A, § 1, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-66 Permitted Devices.
   No person shall use or cause or permit to be used an alarm system utilizing
signaling devices that automatically select a public trunkline of the police
department of the Town of Schererville and then reproduce any prerecorded
message to report any robbery, burglary, fire, hazard, or other emergency. With
the exception of local alarms, only signaling devices shall be permitted to be
installed in the Town for the purpose of reporting any robbery, burglary, fire,
hazard, or other emergency to the police department of the town.
(Ord. No. 1385-A, § 2, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-67 Monitoring System.
   The Police Department of the Town is authorized to contract for the
installation of and maintain a Signal Board within the Police Department of the
Town.
(Ord. No. 977, § 3, 4-10-85)
Sec. 4-68 Permit Required to Operate.
   a.   An alarm user shall not install, operate or maintain an alarm system in
the Town without first obtaining a permit as required herein.
   b.   Any alarm user who operates an alarm system without first obtaining a
permit as required by this section, or who, after having a permit revoked,
fails to disconnect his alarm system, shall be in violation of this Division.
(Ord. No. 977, § 4, 4-10-85)
Sec. 4-69 Application for Permit.
   a.   Every alarm user shall file with the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town, an
application for permit to install, maintain and operate an alarm system in the
Town.
   b.   The alarm user applying for the permit shall complete an application
form as provided and prescribed by the Departments of Police and Fire. Every
permittee shall update any material change in the information provided in the
application whenever such change occurs.
   c.   The information contained in the application as required by this
ordinance and other information received by the Chief of Police through
correspondence or communications with an alarm user shall be secured,
maintained and restricted in its inspection and review to the Chief of Police
and to employees of the town specifically assigned the responsibility for
handling and processing alarm user permit applications. Town employees and
others assigned the duty to handle and process this information shall not
knowingly or willfully reveal the information to any person other than for the
purpose specifically related to this ordinance or specifically related to
official law enforcement matters without the express written consent of the
alarm user.
   d.   Upon receipt of the application for permit, the Clerk-Treasurer shall
distribute the basic information therein to the building inspector, police
chief and fire chief. Each such person shall make such inspection and inquiry
as is reasonable and necessary to determine that the equipment complies with
industry standards and that the alarm equipment supplier has secured a business
license and other permits required by the Town of Schererville and the State of
Indiana. Each such person shall notify the Clerk-Treasurer within seven (7)
days of his approval or rejection of the application, and if rejected, shall
state specifically in writing the basis for his objection. If all such persons
approve the application, the clerk-treasurer shall issue the permit.
   e.   Upon receipt of the updated material change, the applicant shall file a
new application which shall be processed in the same manner provided for an
initial application and in conformity with other provisions of this ordinance.
(Ord. No. 1385-A, § 5, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-69A Yearly Service Fee.
   Every alarm user shall, prior to installation of an alarm system, pay a
registration fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). (Every alarm user incorporating a
Direct Line or Public Trunkline into the communication center of the Police
Department shall pay in addition to the registration fee one hundred dollars ($
100.00) per year fee for the privilege of accessing said line.)
   Every existing alarm user not incorporating either a Direct Line or Public
Trunkline directly into the communication center of the Police Department may
register with the Clerk-Treasurer their alarm system upon the completion of the
appropriate registration form and payment of the registration fee.
(Ord. No. 13 85A, § 6, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-70 Certification by Alarm Equipment Supplier.
   a.   Within ten (10) days after the initial installation of an alarm system,
and within ten (10) days after a modification of an existing alarm system, the
alarm equipment supplier shall deliver to the Clerk-Treasurer a certification
by it that the alarm system is installed and operating in accordance with
standard industry practices and in compliance with applicable laws and
ordinances.
(Ord. No. 1385A, § 7, 7-9-97)
   b.   No permit shall be issued by the Clerk-Treasurer without the
satisfactory compliance with the certification required herein.
(Ord. No. 977, § 6, 4-10-85)
Sec. 4-71 Inspection.
   a.   The Chief of Police, or his designate, shall have the right to inspect
any Alarm System on the premises where it is intended to be used, both prior to
and subsequent to the issuance of a permit, at reasonable times, for the
purpose of determining whether a permit should be granted and/or continued, and
to determine if said Alarm System is being used in conformity with the terms of
the permit, industry standards, and in compliance with applicable laws and
ordinances.
   b.   Upon evidence of frequent false alarms or other good cause as evidenced
in writing, the Chief of Police or his delegate is authorized by each Alarm
User, but not required, to have the Alarm System inspected by an Alarm
Equipment Supplier licensed by the Town for such purpose. Any costs incurred
for said inspection shall be the responsibility of the licensee, and shall in
no way be the responsibility of the Town of Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1385 A, § 8, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-72 Local Alarms.
   a.   Local alarms with any externally audible alert shall not make a sound
similar to that of Civil Defense Warning Systems.
   b.   Such local alarms in residential districts must have an automatic cut-
off after thirty (30) minutes of sounding.
(Ord. No. 1385A, § 9, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-73 Fines Applicable for False Alarms.
   a.   Any Alarm User who has more than two (2) false alarms in any calendar
year shall be fined for each false alarm in excess thereof occurring within the
same calendar year. The fine shall be in the amount of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) for each false alarm thereafter.
   b.   A fine shall be due and payable by the Alarm User within ten (10)
business days after written notice of the violation.
   c.   All fines shall be payable to the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town and
deposited to the General Fund.
(Ord. No. 977, § 9, 4-10-85)
Sec. 4-74 Registration Fees, Yearly Service Fee.
   a.   Every alarm user shall, prior to installation of an alarm system, pay a
registration fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). Every alarm user incorporating a
Direct Line or Public Trunk Line into the communication center of the Police
Department, shall pay in addition to the registration tee, a twenty dollar
($20.00) per month fee for the privilege of accessing said line.
   b.   Every existing alarm user not incorporating either a Direct Line or
Public Trunk Line directly into the communication center of the Police
Department may register with the Clerk-Treasurer their alarm system upon the
completion of the appropriate registration form and payment of the registration
fee.
(Ord. No. 1211, § 1, 6-29-92)
Sec. 4-75 False Alarm Administrative Fees, Failure to Disconnect Penalty.
   a.   Any alarm user having more that three (3) false alarms in a six (6) -
month period shall pay a fine in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
additional false alarm beyond the three (3) occurrences, said fines payable to
the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Schererville to be deposited according to
applicable ordinances, within ten (10) days after notice of said violation.
   b.   Any person who refuses to disconnect their alarm system once their
permit to install, operate or maintain has been revoked as provided in Section
Ten (10) of Ordinance #977, shall be subject to having the permit revoked
pursuant to Section Ten (10) of Ordinance #1077 and Section Five (5) of
Ordinance #1083.
   c.   Failure to pay any fee or fine after thirty (30) days notice may result
in civil penalty up to twice the amount of fee or fine and said person shall be
liable for all attorney's fees and expenses incurred in the collection of said
fee or fine.
(Ord. No. 1211, § 2, 6-29-92; Ord. No. 1385A, § 10, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-76 Revocation of Permit.
   a.   The Clerk-Treasurer may revoke any permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of this ordinance upon a finding of any one or more of the following
violations:
      1.   False information in an application for issuance of a permit for an
Alarm System;
      2.   Failure to comply with any provision of this ordinance, as amended
from time to time, and any other Ordinance of the Town of Schererville,
Indiana;
      3.   Violation of any criminal law of the State of Indiana or the United
States of America;
      4.   Installation, maintenance or operation of an Alarm System in
violation of this Ordinance or of any term or condition of the permit granting
authority;
      5.   Failure to pay any fine charged hereunder;
      6.   Failure to obey an order of the Police Chief to disconnect the Alarm
System;
      7.   Excessive twelve (12) false alarms.
   b.   Before exercising his power to revoke any permit issued hereunder, the
Clerk-Treasurer shall first give written notice to the Alarm User, describing
therein the violation or failure by the Alarm User, and advising the Alarm User
that:
      1.   He shall have a reasonable time, but not exceeding five (5) business
days, to cure the matter and effect compliance, or
      2.   He shall provide to the Chief of Police, or his authorized
representative, such additional information and data as the Alarm User believes
sufficient to deny or excuse the claim of violation or failure.
   An alarm system user whose authorization has been revoked is not precluded
under this Section from applying for a new authorization pursuant to Sec. 4-69.
Provided, however, that before a new permit is issued, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall have a report from the Police Chief as hereinafter defined and in
addition, all fines due must be paid and the system corrected from any
deficiencies. Before the Clerk-Treasure shall issue a new permit, the Police
Chief shall make reasonable efforts to determine that the alarm user's system
has been properly serviced and its deficiencies corrected. The Police Chief
shall notify the Clerk-Treasurer that the alarm system meets all requirements
and that the system has been corrected from its previous deficiencies and upon
all fines being paid, the Clerk-Treasurer shall then issue a new permit
provided all requirements of Sec. 4-69 are complied with.
(Ord. No. 1385A, § 11, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-77 Disconnection.
   a.   Whenever the Police Department become aware of Alarm conditions that
evidence a failure of the Alarm Equipment or the Alarm User to comply with the
requirements of this Division, the Chief of Police may order that the Alarm
User disconnect such Alarm System until it is made to comply with the
requirements of this Division. If there are more than twelve (12) false alarms
in any one calendar year from any Alarm System, the Chief of Police may remove
the Alarm System from the Signal Board.
   b.   No action of disconnection shall take place unless the Chief of Police
first gives written notice of his intention to do so, and the date on which the
action will be taken; provided, however, that in the event the Chief of Police
deems that an action of disconnection is necessary for the public health or
safety, he may disconnect the Alarm System immediately and provide the Alarm
User with prompt notification thereof.
(Ord. No. 977, § 11, 4-10-85)
   c.   Any person effected by the Police Chiefs order to disconnect or by the
Police Chiefs refusal to certify to the Clerk-Treasurer that the system
currently meets all requirements, shall have the right to request the
Metropolitan Board of Police Commissioners to review the decision or action
taken by the Police Chief by requesting review within ten (10) days after any
adverse action or decision made by the Police Chief.
(Ord. No. 1385A, § 12, 7-9-97)
Sec. 4-78 Hold Harmless.
   In the event that an Alarm User or an Alarm Equipment Supplier has violated
or failed to comply with any provision of this Division such Alarm User and
such Alarm Equipment Supplier shall hold the Town, or any of its officials,
employees, and/or agents, harmless from any cost, expense, claim or the like
incurred or paid by the Town arising out of or occurring as a result of the
installation and operation of an Alarm System within the Town, including but
not limited to, reasonable attorney fees, litigation expenses and court costs.
   The Alarm User and the Alarm Equipment Supplier, by applying for a permit,
and by installing Alarm System within the Town of Schererville, waive any claim
or cause of action which either may have against the Town for acts or actions
taken by the Town of Schererville, or any of its officials, employees, and/or
agents in good faith.
(Ord. No. 977, § 12, 4-10-85)
Sec. 4-79 through Sec. 4-81 Reserved for Future Use.
Division VI. Peddlers, Hawkers, Salesmen, Solicitors, Canvassers, and Transient
Merchants.  6
 
Notes
6 6   I.C., § 25-37-1-11, permits towns and cities to lax. license and regulate
  transient merchants and charge a fee lor the transaction of business.
Sec. 4-82 Definitions.
   a.   As used in this Division the word "peddler" and "hawker" shall mean a
salesman, trader or any person who carries an exhibit in any manner and
products, goods, wares, or merchandise of any kind for the purpose of selling
or offering for sale barter or exchange any product, goods, wares or
merchandise of any kind or description whatsoever, traveling by foot, vehicle
or other conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or in, about,
along or upon any street, alley or highway, or any other grounds in the Town of
Schererville, Lake County, Indiana.
   b.   The word "solicitor" and/or "canvasser" shall include any person taking
or attempting to take orders for the sale of products, goods, wares and
merchandise of any kind or description whatsoever, for future delivery, or for
services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such person
has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or
whether he is collecting advance payment on such sales or not, traveling by
foot or any type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or
in, along, about, any street or place within the corporate limits of the Town
of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana. "Solicitor" shall include, but not be
limited to those soliciting the taking of photographs.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 1, 5-10-89)
   c.   The word "Fundraiser" shall apply to any person requesting cash
donations or product in lieu of cash, by traveling by foot, vehicle, or other
conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or in, about, along, or
upon any street, alley, or highway, or any other grounds in the Town of
Schererville, Lake County, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 1403, § 1, 11-26-97)
   d.   For the purpose of this Division, a transient merchant is defined as
any person, firm or corporation, whether a resident of the Town of Schererville
or not, who engages in a temporary business or itinerant business of selling
and delivering goods or products of any kind within the said Town of
Schererville, and who, in furtherance of said purpose, hires, leases, uses or
occupies any building, structure, vehicle, room, shop or other place within the
said Town, for the exhibition and sale of such products, goods, wares, and
merchandise.
   e.   The word "person" as used herein shall include the singular and plural
and shall also mean and include any person, firm or partnership, or society or
any entity organization.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 1, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-1)
Sec. 4-83 License and Registration Required.
   a.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or carry on the
business of peddling or hawking or to be a peddler or hawker, within the Town,
without first obtaining a license as provided herein for that purpose,
   b.   It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit within the Town of
Schererville for the sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, by contract or
any other manner of provision of payment or for future payment or delivery,
without first procuring a license as provided herein.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 2, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-2)
   c.   It shall be unlawful to act as a "Fundraiser" in the Town of
Schererville, Indiana, unless the individual and/or organization provides
documentation establishing that they are a not-for-profit organization
certified under Section 26 United States Code, § 501(c)(3) of the Internal
Revenue Code. Upon satisfying said prerequisite, the individual must obtain a
license as set forth in this ordinance.
(Ord. No. 1403, § 2, 11-26-97)
Sec. 4-84 Exceptions.
   Nothing in this Division shall be held to include persons selling for a bona
fide wholesale establishment to retail dealers in the Town, nor to acts of bona
fide local merchants or businesses of Schererville or their employees in taking
orders in the house of their customers for goods or services, or to the acts of
said merchants or businessmen or their employees in delivering goods so ordered
by their customers, nor to any child under the age of 13. Nor shall this
Ordinance apply to clubs or organizations making sales on a charitable or non-
profit basis. The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue a free license to any approved
applicant who has been a war veteran or serviceman who shall present to the
Clerk-Treasurer a license from the county auditor showing his qualifications
under Indiana Code, § 25-25-2-1 (Burns Indiana Statutes Annotated - Code
Edition)
(Ord. No. 1105, § 3, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-3)
Sec. 4-85 Application.
   An application for the license required by this Division containing the
following information shall be furnished the Clerk-Treasurer two (2) weeks
prior to the issuance of the license:
   a.   The applicant's name, home address and local address, if any;
   b.   A photograph and physical description of the applicant, setting forth
the applicant's age, sex, height, weight, date of birth, social security
number, race, complexion, color of hair and eyes and other distinguishing
features;
   c.   The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two
reliable property owners of the county of Lake, State of Indiana, who will
certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or,
in lieu thereof, other evidence as to good character, sufficient to make an
evaluation as to character and responsibility;
   d.   The name and address or principal office of the person, if any, for or
through whom or under those auspices the applicant is authorized to conduct
such activity, or a statement that the applicant is engaged in such activity
solely on his own behalf;
   e.   A brief description of the type of goods, wares or merchandise to be
sold and a statement whether delivery of such goods, wares or merchandise is to
be made immediately or in the future;
   f.   Each applicant dealing in an edible product or traveling from house to
house shall file with his application a statement by a reputable physician of
the Town of Schererville, dated not more than ten (10) days prior to submission
of the application, certifying the applicant and goods to be free of
infectious, contagious, or communicable disease, or contaminants;
   g.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of
any crime or misdemeanor and, if so, the nature of the offense and the
punishment assessed therefore, the date and location and Court of such
conviction;
   h.   If the applicant canvasser or solicits orders for such wares, goods or
merchandise, a sample copy of the order or receipt form used by him in
connection with such activity;
   i.    The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
   j.    If a vehicle is to be used, a description of same, together with
license number or other means of identification.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 4,5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-4)
Sec. 4-86 Processing of Application.
   Upon receipt of such application, the original shall be referred to the
Chief of Police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business
and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the
public.
   If the applicant's character and responsibility is found to be
unsatisfactory, the Chief of Police shall endorse on such application his
disapproval and his reason for same, and return the said application to the
Clerk-Treasurer who shall notify applicant that his application is disapproved
and that no license will be issued. If the character and responsibility of the
applicant are found to be satisfactory, the Chief of Police shall endorse on
the application his approval, and return said application to the Clerk-
Treasurer, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee, use a license and
deliver it to the applicant. Such license shall contain the signature of the
Clerk-Treasurer and show the name, address and photograph of said license,
class of license issued and kind of goods to be sold thereunder, and the
expiration date. The Clerk-Treasurer shall keep a permanent record of all
licenses issued.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 5, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-5)
Sec. 4-87 Fees.
   a.   A license fee shall be charged by the Clerk-Treasurer shall be five
dollars ($5.00) per week, or ten dollars ($10.00) per month, or one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year.
   b.   Vehicles - For each vehicle used, said applicant shall file a
certificate of insurance with the Clerk-Treasurer establishing that liability
insurance in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
bodily injury and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) property damage is
in effect, and that each vehicle so used shall have displayed upon each side
thereof, in plain print, legible at twenty feet, the name, address of owner,
any kind of goods for sale. A fee for each vehicle used shall be paid in the
amount of five dollars ($5.00) per month, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per half
year, or fifty dollars ($50.00) per year.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 6, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-6)
Sec. 4-88 Badge Required.
   Any and all persons procuring a license under this Division shall wear
conspicuously upon his person a badge reflecting his permission and license
which shall be furnished by the Town and shall not be transferable. A five
dollar ($5.00) deposit for such badge shall be required of all such persons
which deposit shall be returned o depositor upon the return of the badge to the
Clerk-Treasurer within five (5) days of expiration of said license.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 7, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-7)
Sec. 4-89 Expiration of License.
   All annual licenses issued under this Division shall expire on the 31st day
of December in the year when issued and all other licenses shall expire on the
date specified on said license.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 8, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-8)
Sec. 4-90 Hours of Soliciting.  7
   It shall be unlawful for any house-to-house peddler, hawker, solicitor and/
or canvasser to use other than the front door when making calls at residences;
and all such soliciting and/or canvassing shall be done between the hours of 9:
00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. with the exception that all soliciting or canvassing on
Sundays and holidays shall be prohibited.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 9, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-9)
 
Notes
7 7   Editor's Note: At the request of the Town, the hour was changed from "9:00
  p.m." to "5:00 p.m." during the recodification process.
Sec. 4-91 Possession of License Required.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to call at any residence or place of
business within the Town of Schererville, with the intent or purpose of
soliciting as provided in this Division, without having in his or her
possession a license authorizing such solicitation. No license shall be in the
possession of any person other than the one to whom it is issued.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 10, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-10)
Sec. 4-92 Sounding of Bells, Etc., Prohibited.
   No person nor any licensed peddler, or solicitor traveling by foot, wagon,
motor vehicle, or any other type of conveyance shall make a noise by hawking,
sound or cause to be sounded any horn, bell, whistle, loud speaker, or other
noisemaking device for the purpose of attracting attention of the public to the
presence of such vehicle, or as a medium on advertising the sale of such
merchandise.
(Ord. No. 1105, § II, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-11)
Sec. 4-93 License for Use of Public Property by Commercial Photographers.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy or use any portion of a public
street, public sidewalk, public park, or other public property, within the
limits of the Town of Schererville, for the taking of photographs, pictures, or
motion pictures with the intent or purpose of selling, or offering the same for
sale, without first having obtained a license.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 12, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-12)
Sec. 4-94 Permanent Structure, Compliance With All Applicable Zonings, Health
and Building Ordinance Regulations or Statutes.
   a.   Any person obtaining a license for the sale of barter or exchange of
goods wares or services to be sold from a stationary structure building,
edifice, or place, must comply with all applicable zoning, health, building
ordinances, regulations or statutes or other applicable laws prior to
commencing business within the Town of Schererville.
   b.   The issuance of a license to carry on business under this Division does
not absolve in licensee from the requirement as described in Section
4-94 'a'.
(Ord. No. 1105, § 13, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-13)
Sec. 4-95 Penalty for Violation.
   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Division shall be
fined in a sum not to exceed One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) each day that any
person shall violate any of the provision or section of this Division shall be
deemed a separate offense hereunder. Each day such violation is committed shall
constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. No, 1105, § 14, 5-10-89; Schererville Town Code, § 5-2-14)
Sec. 4-96 through Sec. 4-99 Reserved for Future Use.
Division VII. Outdoor Events-Circuses, Carnivals, Etc.
Sec. 4-100 Outdoor Events Governed.
   Outdoor events are intended to include any circus, carnival, bizarre,
festival, exhibition, athletic contests, outdoor beer gardens, and other public
spectacles or outdoor events which are detrimental to the health, safety,
welfare and protection of the citizens of the Town of Schererville. This
Division is not intended to include established businesses such as private
clubs or other established private organizations or associations.
(Ord. No. 936, § 1, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-101 Permit Required.
   a.   No person, firm, corporation, organization or association, foreign or
domestic, shall erect or maintain any structure, building, stand, platform, or
operate any machinery on any municipally owned real estate in the Town of
Schererville, Indiana, for use in connection with the operation or maintenance
of any circus, carnival, bizarre, festival, exhibition, athletic contest,
outdoor beer gardens, or any other public spectacle, until and unless such
person, firm, corporation, organization or association, foreign or domestic,
has first obtained a permit, as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. No. 936, § 2, 8-14-83)
   b.   No person, firm, corporation, organization, or association, foreign or
domestic, shall operate or maintain or permit the operation or maintenance of
any circus, carnival, bizarre, festival, exhibition, athletic contest, outdoor
beer gardens, or any other public spectacle, on any privately owned real estate
in the Town of Schererville, Indiana, unless and until such person, form,
corporation, organization or association, foreign or domestic, has first
obtained a permit as hereafter provided.
(Ord. No. 936, § 3, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-102 Regulations Addressing Alcoholic Beverages at Outdoor Events.
   Any person, firm, corporation, organization or association, foreign or
domestic, sponsor-ing or operating an outdoor event which dispenses and serves
beer and/or liquor must rope or block off said area where beer and/or liquor is
dispensed and served, with only one (1) entrance to this area and said area
must be posted with a "No Minors" sign. Responsibility for ascertaining age (21
or over) lies with the sponsor or operator of the event. Serving of any beer
and/or liquor must end no later than 11:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and
10:00 p.m. Sunday.
(Ord. No. 936, § 4, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-103 Noise Regulations at Outdoor Events.
   Any outdoor event which has any type of outside music, loud speakers or
other form of amplification must end said music or amplification no later than
11:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday and no later than 10:00 p.m. on Sundays.
Undue or excessively loud music or other noise resulting from the operation of
an outdoor event will not be permitted and is subject to regulation by the
Chief of Police of the Town of Schererville or an authorized representative
from the Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 936, § 5, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-104 Parking Requirements.
   Definite parking areas must be established in cooperation with the
Schererville Police Department, to accommodate any outdoor event. Residential
streets shall not be used for parking for said outdoor event, unless permitted
by the Chief of Police of the Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 936, § 6, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-105 Security Required.
   All outdoor events shall be required to provide security for said event. The
amount and degree of security shall be determined by the Chief of Police of the
Schererville Police Department.
(Ord. No. 936, § 7, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-106 Insurance Requirements.
   Any sponsors or operators of an outdoor event will be required to show proof
of financial responsibility in the form of liability insurance to cover injury
to person or property of not less than one millions dollars ($1,000,000.00) in
respect of bodily injury or death to any one person and not less than three
million dollars ($3,000,000.00) in respect of any one occurrence or accident,
and not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property
damage. No permit shall be issued until said proof of liability insurance is
submitted with the Application for Permit.
(Ord. No. 936, § 8, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-107 Inspections Required.
   Any sponsors or operators of an outdoor event shall be required to have an
electrical and fire inspection by the Town of Schererville prior to the
commencement of said outdoor event.
(Ord. No. 936, § 9, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-108 Permit Fee.
   Applications for permits contemplated under the provisions of this Ordinance
shall be made upon the forms prescribed by the Town Council of the Town of
Schererville, Indiana, and shall be filed with the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town
of Schererville, Indiana. Each and every such application, except applications
of not-for-profit associations or organizations, shall be accompanied by a
filing fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which fee shall be
paid to the Clerk-Treasurer. Such application shall be filed not less than ten
(10) days prior to the meeting of the Town Council of the Town of Schererville,
Indiana, at which time the same is to be considered and granted or denied. The
Clerk-Treasurer shall furnish copies of said application to the Fire Chief,
Police Chief, and each member of the Town Council of the Town of Schererville,
Indiana.
(Ord. No. 936, § 10, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-109 Issuance of Permit.
   In the event that the Town Council of the Town of Schererville, Indiana,
shall grant said application and direct the Clerk-Treasurer to issue said
permit, the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Schererville, Indiana, shall
thereupon issue a permit to the applicant upon a form prescribed by the Town
Council of the Town of Schererville, Indiana consistent with the provisions of
this Division.
(Ord. No. 936, § 11, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-110 Penalties.
   Any person, firm, corporation, organization or association, foreign or
domestic, operating or sponsoring an outdoor event as defined in Section
4-100, who violates any of the provisions of this Division shall be liable for
a fine up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Further, the Chief
of Police of the Town of Schererville, Indiana, or an authorized representative
from the Police Department of the Town of Schererville, Indiana, shall have the
authority to close down any outdoor event for flagrant violation of any of the
provisions of this Division and to confiscate the permit issued by the Town of
Schererville, Indiana.
(Ord. No. 936, § 12, 8-14-83)
Sec. 4-111 through Sec. 4-113 Reserved for Future Use.
Division VIII. Ambulance Services.
Sec. 4-114 Ambulance Service Rates.
   The Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana, shall charge the following
rates for ambulance emergency medical services and related provided by the Town
of Schererville Metropolitan Fire Department Ambulance Service commencing on
August 1, 2021:
   a.   Basic Life Support (BLS) Transport Fees.
      1.   Residents of the Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana,
receiving ambulance and related emergency medical services, which services
include transport, shall be charged the amount of seven hundred sixty-eight
dollars ($768.00) per call, and shall be charged twenty-four and 50/100 dollars
($24.50) per mile traveled.
      2.   Non-residents receiving ambulance and related emergency medical
services, which services include transport, shall be charged the amount of one
thousand one hundred nine dollars ($1,109.00) per call, and shall be charged
twenty-four and 50/100 dollars ($24.50) per mile traveled.
      3.   Residents of the Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana,
receiving ambulance and related emergency medical services consisting of
treatment and site release shall be charged the amount of two hundred fifty-six
dollars ($256.00) per call. The rates and charges herein for treatment and site
release shall be inclusive of lift assistance in any care facility or
residential home wherein request was made and service response of the Town
Metropolitan Fire Department occurred. This user fee/rate charge shall be made
to each of the owner/operator of the care facility, or the owner/occupant of
the residential property. The user fees charged for such lift assistance and
care at a care facility or at a residential property shall be charged, and upon
collection, such rates and charges shall be deposited for Fire Department use
in the Town Special Ambulance Equipment Non-Reverting Fund, with use thereafter
to be in conformance with the rules, regulations and requirements of the
Indiana State Board of Accounts.
      4.   Non-residents receiving ambulance and related emergency medical
services consisting of treatment and site release shall be charged the amount
of four hundred twenty-seven dollars ($427.00) per call. The rates and charges
herein for treatment and site release shall be inclusive of lift assistance in
any care facility or residential home wherein request was made and service
response of the Town Metropolitan Fire Department occurred. This user fee/rate
charge shall be made to each of the owner/operator of the care facility, or the
owner/occupant of the residential property. The user fees charged for such lift
assistance and care at a care facility or at a residential property shall be
charged, and upon collection, such rates and charges shall be deposited for
Fire Department use in the Town Special Ambulance Equipment Non-Reverting Fund,
with use thereafter to be in conformance with the rules, regulations and
requirements of the Indiana State Board of Accounts.
   b.   Advance Life Support (ALS, Level 1) Transport Fees. For the Advance
Life Support, Level 1, Level of Service, the same shall be defined as set forth
and provided hereinafter as described, namely:
      Advance Life Support (ALS), Level 1. Advance Life Support Level 1 (ALS1)
is the transportation by ground ambulance vehicle and the provision of medical
necessary supplies and services including the provision of an ALS assessment of
at least one (1) ALS intervention.
      Advanced Life Support Assessment. Advance life support (ALS) assessment
is an assessment performed by an ALS crew as part of an emergency response that
was necessary because the patient's reported condition at the time of dispatch
was such that only an ALS crew was qualified to perform the assessment. An ALS
assessment does not necessarily result in determining that the patient required
an ALS level of service.
      The determination to respond with an ALS ambulance must be in accord with
the local 911 or equivalent service dispatch protocol.
      1.   Residents of the Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana,
receiving ambulance and related emergency medical services, which services
included transport, shall be charged the amount of one thousand one hundred
ninety-five dollars ($1,195.00) per call, and shall be charged twenty-four and
50/100 dollars ($24.50) per mile traveled.
      2.   Non-residents receiving ambulance and related emergency medical
services, which services include transport, shall be charged the amount of one
thousand four hundred fifty-one dollars ($1,451.00), and shall be charged
twenty-four and 50/100 dollars ($24.50) per mile traveled.
   c.   Advance Life Support (ALS), Level 2 Transport Fees. For the Advance
Life Support Level 2 of service, the same shall be defined as set forth and
provided hereinafter as set forth and provided as described, namely:
      Advance Life Support (ALS), Level 2. Advance life support, Level 2
(ALS2), is the transportation by ground ambulance vehicle and the provision of
medically necessary supplies and services including: (A) at least three (3)
separate administrations of one (1) or more medications by intravenous push/
bolus or by continuous infusion (excluding crystalloid fluids); or (B) ground
ambulance transport and the provision of at least one (1) of the ALS2
recognized and identified procedures.
      1.   Residents of the Town of Schererville, Lake County, Indiana,
receiving ambulance services, which services include transport and are
identified as ALS Level 2, shall be charged the amount of one thousand two
hundred eighty dollars($1,280.00) per call, and shall be charged twenty four
and 50/100 dollars ($24.50) per mile traveled.
      2.   Non-residents receiving ambulance and related emergency medical
services consisting of treatment and site release shall be charged the amount
of one thousand five hundred seventy-nine dollars ($1,579.00) per call, and
shall be charged twenty-four and 50/100 dollars ($24.50) per mile traveled.
(Ord. No. 975B, § 1, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 1516, 3-14-01; Ord. No. 985C, § 1, 3-9-
05; Ord. No. 985D, § 1, 4-13-05; Ord. No. 985E, § 1, 2-8-06; Ord. No. 985H, §
1, 6-11-14; Ord. No. 985J, § 1, 7-14-21)
Sec. 4-115 Ambulance Services - Exceptions.
   a.   It is declared the policy of the Town of Schererville, Lake County,
Indiana, and its Metropolitan Fire Department Ambulance Service, that when
necessary or determined that transport of a person or persons is required, such
person or persons shall be transported to the following hospital care
providers, namely:
      1.   Franciscan St. Margaret health in Dyer, Indiana; or
      2.   Methodist Hospital in Merrillville, Indiana; or
      3.   Franciscan Healthcare in Munster, Indiana; or
      4.   Community Hospital in Munster, Indiana; or
      5.   Franciscan St. Anthony Health in Crown Point, Indiana.
   b.   The determination as to the place of transport shall be in the sole
discretion of the Town of Schererville Fire Department Ambulance Service
personnel on scene responsible on-site for such matters. The following are the
only exceptions to the aforementioned Town policy, namely:
      1.   In a life-threatening situation or circumstance, the responsible
Town Fire Department Ambulance personnel shall have the option to direct
transport to the nearest hospital.
      2.   In the event of rendering ambulance and related emergency medical
services pursuant to Mutual Aid assistance, then transport may be made to any
hospital.
   c.   The Indiana Trauma Rule, currently cited at 836 IAC 1-2.1, and as the
same is amended hereafter from time to time, is hereby adopted as the
Schererville Metropolitan Fire Department Ambulance Service Trauma Policy.
(Ord. No. 985A, § 2, 3-12-97; Ord. No. 985B, § 2, 10-13-99; Ord. No. 985I, § 2,
1-13-16)
Sec. 4-116 Policy Regarding Deceased Persons.
   The Schererville Fire Department ambulance shall not be used for the
transportation of deceased persons.
(Ord. No. 985, § 3, 8-26-85)
Sec. 4-117 Patient Transfer Policy.
   Patient transfers to or from any hospital will not be handled by the
Schererville Fire Department ambulance. Transfers of this type shall be
arranged on a private basis by the person concerned.
(Ord. No. 985, § 4, 8-26-85)
Sec. 4-118 Refusal of Service Form.
   Any conscious person eighteen (18) years of age or older shall have the
right to refuse ambulance service provided, however, a "refusal of service
form" shall be signed by any person refusing said service. If a person refuses
said service and also refuses to sign a "refusal of service form" said form
shall be signed on behalf of said person by any law enforcement officer present
at the time said refusal is made.
(Ord. No. 985, § 5, 8-26-85)
Sec. 4-119 Billings by Clerk-Treasurer.
   a.   The Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Schererville shall bill and collect
all charges made for service pursuant to this Division. Collection shall be
enforced as needed in the name of the Town of Schererville by the town
attorney.
   b.   The Ambulance Fund is addressed in Section
2-396 of this Code.
Sec. 4-120 Ambulance Run Reports.
   a.   The Town of Schererville Fire Department shall charge a fee of five
dollars ($5.00) for each Ambulance Run Report which is furnished to any person
lawfully entitled to receive said information.
   b.   All fees for Ambulance Run Reports shall be deposited into a separate
account known as the EMT Fund.
(Ord. No. 1517, 3-14-01)
Sec. 4-121 through Sec. 4-147 Reserved for Future Use.

Division XII. Licensing of Dogs and Cats.
Sec. 4-175 Animal Licensing Required.
   Any person owning, keeping, harboring, or having custody of any animal over
three (3) months of age within this town must obtain a license as herein
provided. This provision may not apply to small cage birds or to aquatic and
amphibian animals kept solely as pets.
(Ord. No. 1549, § 3, 1-23-02)
Sec. 4-176 Application.
   Written application for licenses, which shall include name and address of
applicant, description of the animal, the appropriate fee, and rabies
certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian or anti-rabies clinic, shall be
made to the licensing authority.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [b], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-177 Duration of License.
   If not revoked, licenses for the keeping of dogs and cats shall be for a
period of one (1) year.
(Ord. No. 1549, § 3, 1-23-02)
Sec. 4-178 Deadlines for Filing Application.
   Application for a license must be made within thirty (30) days after
obtaining a dog or cat over three (3) months of age; this requirement will not
apply to a nonresident keeping a dog or cat within the town for not longer than
thirty (30) days.
(Ord. No. 1549, § 3, 1-23-02)
Sec. 4-179 Exemptions.
   (A)   License fees shall not be required for certified Seeing Eye dogs,
hearing dogs, governmental police dogs, or other certified dogs that are
trained to assist the physically handicapped.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [e], 5-12-93)
   (B)   Animals rented solely for the purpose of guarding a business or
residence are exempt from this subsection.
(Ord. No. 1549, § 3, 1-23-02)
Sec. 4-180 License Tag Issued by Clerk-Treasurer.
   Upon acceptance of the license application and fee, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall issue a durable tag or identification collar, stamped with an identifying
number and the year of issuance. Tags should be designed so that they may be
conveniently fastened or riveted to the animal's collar or harness.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [f], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-181 Identification Tags to be Worn at All Times.
   Dogs and cats must wear identification tags or collars at all times when off
the premises of the owners.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [g], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-182 Records and Licensing Period.
   a.   The licensing authority shall maintain a record of the identifying
numbers of all tags issued and shall make this record available to the public.
   b.   The licensing period shall begin with the fiscal year and shall run for
one (1) year. A license application may be made thirty (30) days prior to, and
up to March 31st of the fiscal year.
(Ord. 1549, § 3, 1-23-02)
Sec. 4-183 Fines.
   Persons who fail to obtain a license as required within the time period
specified in this section will be subjected to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [j], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-184 Fees.
   a.   A license shall be issued after payment of the following application
fee:
      unneutered male dog   $20.00      neutered male dog   $5.00
      unneutered male cat   $10.00      neutered male cat   $5.00
      unspayed female dog   $20.00      spayed female dog   $5.00
      unspayed female cat   $10.00      spayed female cat   $5.00
      breeder permit      $25.00
   b.   A duplicate license may be obtain upon payment of a one dollar ($1.00)
replacement fee.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [k] [l], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-185 Non-transferring of License.
   No person may use any license for any animal other than the animal for which
it was issued.
(Ord. No. 1236, § 3 [m], 5-12-93)
Sec. 4-186 Commercial Animal Establishments and Animal Shelters.
   a.   Annual permits shall be issued upon payment of the applicable fee:
      1.    Kennel authorized to house fewer than six dogs or cats         $
150.00
      2.    Kennel authorized to house six or more but fewer than 10 dogs or
cats   $ 200.00
      3.    Kennel authorized to house 10 or more dogs or cats            $
250.00
      4.    Breeder permits                        $ 100.00
      5.    Pet shops                           $ 200.00
      6.    Riding Stable                           $ 100.00
      7.    Auction                           $ 100.00
      8.    Zoological park                        $ 200.00
      9.    Circus                              $ 200.00
      10.    Grooming shops                        $ 50.00
      11.    Petting Zoo                           $ 150.00
      12.    Guard-dog training center                     $ 200.00
      13.    Miscellaneous Hunting Permits                  $ 5.00
   b.   Every facility regulated by this ordinance shall be considered a
separate enterprise requiring an individual permit.
   c.   No more than five (5) dogs and/or cats combined over the age of three
months may be kept on any residential, commercial or other premises within the
town unless the owner or owners of the animals hold a valid permit.
   d.   No fee may be required of any veterinary hospital, animal shelter, or
government operated zoological park.
(Ord. No. 1549, § 4 [g]-[i], [m], 1-23-02; Ord. No. 1626, § 2, 10-13-04)
Sec. 4-187 Reserved for Future Use.
Division XIII. Sale and Solicitations Prohibited on Public Streets and
Intersections.
Sec. 4-188 Soliciting on Public Streets and Intersections Prohibited - Penalty.
   a.   It shall be, and is declared to be, unlawful for any person, firm,
group, association, corporation or entity of any kind, public or private, for
profit or not for profit, commercial or charitable, to sell or solicit for
sale, or to cause to be sold or solicited for sale, or to seek contributions,
for or in exchange for, any goods, merchandise or commodities, or cause, in the
Town of Schererville, Indiana, upon or on any public street, highway, road or
thoroughfare, or at or in any intersection of such public streets and/or roads
and/or highways and/or thoroughfares in or bounding said Town.
(Ord. No. 1153, § 2, 7-11-90)
   b.   Any person violating the foregoing provisions of this Section, or
causing violation of said provisions of this Section shall, for each day of
said violation, be fined a sum not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
day, per person.
(Ord. No. 1153, § 3, 7-11-90)
Sec. 4-189 Reserved for Future Use.
Division XIV. Fire Department Fees.
Sec. 4-190 Fees for Responses to Hazardous and Toxic Material Spills and Leaks.
   Shippers, transporters, owners of automobiles and other vehicles, and
including owners (or tenants) of fixed facilities within the Town of
Schererville, who cause or suffer leaks or spills of potentially hazardous or
toxic materials within the Town of Schererville, either at fixed side
facilities or on local roads and highways (other than state highways), to such
leaks or spills the Schererville Fire Department must initially respond, shall
pay the Town of Schererville within thirty (30) days as compensation and
reimbursement for providing said response services, the appropriate sums of
money set forth in the approved schedule of fees adopted through the State Fire
Marshall's office, those being as follows:
   a.   For initial response with fire engine, trucks, or fire apparatus,
$250.00;
   b.   For each hour or fraction of on-scene assistance, $150.00.
(Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 5-13-92)
Sec. 4-191 Thirty (30) Day Payment Period.
   Shippers, transporters, owners of automobiles and other vehicles, and
including owners (or tenants) of fixed facilities within the Town of
Schererville, who cause or suffer leaks or spills of potentially hazardous or
toxic materials within the Town of Schererville, for which leaks or spills the
Schererville Fire Department vehicles and equipment are used in response, shall
reimburse the Town within thirty (30) days for any such equipment which has
been damaged, destroyed, discarded or otherwise adversely affected, based upon
an estimate obtained accurately stating the cost of said damage.
(Ord. No. 1204, § 2, 5-13-92)
Sec. 4-192 Clean-Up and Clean-Up Contractors.
   Shippers, transports, owners of automobiles and other vehicles, and
including owners (or tenants) of fixed facilities within the Town of
Schererville, who cause or suffer leaks or spills of potentially hazardous or
toxic materials within the Town of Schererville, for the cleanup of which
separate clean-up contractors are required to be called in (in the
determination and at the discretion of the Schererville Fire Department) shall
assume and bear full responsibility for the direct payment for said clean-up to
the clean-up contractor.
(Ord. No. 1204, § 3, 5-13-92)
Sec. 4-193 Billing Procedure.
   The Schererville Fire Department and the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of
Schererville shall be responsible for billing the shippers, transporters,
owners of automobiles and other vehicles, and including owners (or tenants) of
fixed facilities within the Town of Schererville, causes or suffers the leak or
spill, within a reasonable time after the Schererville Fire Department's
initial response to the said leak or spill, for the use of Schererville Fire
Department's resources.
(Ord. No. 1204, § 4, 5-13-92)
Sec. 4-194 Penalty for Failure to Pay.
   Shippers, transporters, owners of automobiles and other vehicles, and
including owners (or tenants) of fixed facilities within the Town of
Schererville, who cause or suffer leaks or spills of potentially hazardous or
toxic materials within the Town of Schererville, who fail to reimburse the Town
within thirty (30) days after receipt of said billing, shall be deemed to have
violated this Division and shall suffer a penalty, in addition to the
determined reimbursement, as provided in applicable Ordinances of the Town of
Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1204, § 5, 5-13-92)
Sec. 4-195 Fire Investigation Reports.
   a.   The Town of Schererville Fire Department shall charge a fee of five
dollars ($5.00) for each Fire Investigation Report which is furnished to any
person lawfully entitled to receive said information.
   b.   All fees for Fire Investigation Reports shall be deposited into a
separate account known as the Fire Equipment Fund.
(Ord. No. 1517, 3-14-01)
Sec. 4-196 through Sec. 4-199 Reserved for Future Use.
Division XV. Police Department Fees.
Sec. 4-200 Licensing of Handguns - Procedures and Fees.
   a.   Pursuant to Indiana Code, § 35-47-2-1, et seq., more particularly
Indiana Code, § 35-4-2-1, a person desiring a license to carry a handgun shall
apply to the Chief of Police or Acting Chief of Police of the Town of
Schererville, providing the applicant is a resident of the Town of
Schererville.
(Ord. No. 1087, § 2, 10-12-88)
   b.   The Police Department by and through its Chief or Acting Chief or
designee shall make available the forms recommended by the Indiana State Police
or other designated proper agency, and shall assist the applicant in properly
filling out said forms and providing other required information and data.
(I.C., § 35-47-2-3).
   c.   The Police Department, Chief or Acting Chief, or other designee does
not have discretion to grant or deny licenses or applications except as
provided by State Law. The Police Department, Chief or Acting Chief, or their
designee then shall forward the application to the Indiana State Police or
other proper agency as a ministerial function only. The Police Department,
Police Chief, Acting Police Chief, or their designee or the Town of
Schererville does not have any discretion in the issuing of such licenses, and
does not warrant or take any responsibility for any of the information
contained in or on any application.
(Ord. No. 1087, § 4, 10-12-88)
   d.   The license fee the Police Department shall charge for processing a
handgun application shall be the same as provided under I.C. § 35-47-2-3, as
amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 1141, § 1, 2-14-90)
   e.   The administrative fee provided in I.C. § 35-47-2-3 shall be placed in
an account created by and maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer for law enforcement
training expenses for the Schererville Police Department. Said account to be
maintained with accepted standards of accounting recommended by the Indiana
State Board of Accounts. The disbursement of the funds therefrom shall be in
the discretion of the Superintendent of Police, Chief of Police, Acting Chief
of Police or whoever is at any time the highest ranking person designated as
department head of the Police Department.
(Ord. No. 1087, § 5, 10-12-88; Ord. No. 1674, § 1, 7-12-06)
Sec. 4-201 Out-of-State Vehicle Inspection Fee.
   Whenever an employee of the Schererville Police Department performs and
inspection of a motor vehicle, semi-trailer, or recreational vehicle prior to
its registration in the State of Indiana, pursuant to Indiana Code, § 9-1-2-1,
the Department shall be entitled to charge a fee in an amount of five dollars
($5.00) for each such inspection. The revenue from the inspection fee shall be
deposited in a special vehicle inspection fund (See Sec.
2-402 of this Code). The fiscal body (Town Council) must appropriate the money
collected from the inspection only for law enforcement purposes. (Ord. No.
1069, § 1, 6-8-88) The person inspecting such vehicle shall make a record of
inspection upon the application form, as prepared by the Department, and verify
the facts set out in said application.
   a.   Non-commercial applicants shall pay the inspection fee at the time of
the inspection. A receipt will be issued for each fee collected, on a receipt
form designated, in triplicate, with one (1) copy given to the applicant, one
(1) copy attached to the fee, and one (1) copy remaining in the receipt book.
The fee shall then be deposited in the designated safe and remitted to the
Clerk-Treasurer at least once each week.
   b.   Commercial applications shall be billed on a monthly basis, payable on
or before the 15th day of the following month. All requests for inspections by
auto dealerships shall be recorded on an "assist cash sheet", specifying the
number of vehicles inspected. An inspection form, specifying the date, name of
the business, the number of vehicles inspected, and designated space for
signatures of the commercial representative and the inspecting officer, will be
completed each time, and these forms turned in to the records clerk of the
police department. No fee shall be collected from any commercial applicant by
any employee of the police department without authorization from the station
commander or the Chief of Police.
(Ord. No. 957, § 1, 6-13-84, Schererville Town Code, § 8-9-1)
Sec. 4-202 Fees for Traffic Accident Reports.
   a.   The Schererville Metropolitan Police Department has a legal duty and
obligation pursuant to Indiana Code, § 9-3-1-3 to promptly on demand furnish to
any person who has sustained any loss or damage, by reason of the injury or
death of any person or damage to property caused by or resulting from the
operation, maintenance or use of any vehicle upon any public street or highway
in the State the following information on a police or accident report:
      1.   A name and address of the owner and operator of any vehicle involved
in said accident;
      2.   The license number and description of any such vehicle involved in
said accident;
      3.   The time and place of such accident occurred;
      4.   The names and addresses of any persons injured or killed in said
accident;
      5.   The names and addresses of any persons who were witnesses to said
accident.
   b.   Any person lawfully entitled to the aforesaid information may obtain
the same from the Schererville Metropolitan Police Department either in person
or through his duly authorized agent or attorney, provided that, such agent or
attorney shall first file with said department a verified written authorization
therefore signed by such person so lawfully entitled to said information.
   c.   When such information is furnished by means of a duplicating copy
machine of the investigator's report of said accident, the department shall be
entitled to charge a fee of four dollars ($4.00) for each such police or
accident report.
   d.   Such fee for the aforesaid accident or police report shall be deposited
in a separate account known as the "Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund"
and it may be expended at the discretion of the Chief Administrative Officer of
the department for any department purpose reasonably related to the keeping of
accident reports and records for the prevention of street and highway
accidents. (See §
2-395 of this Code).
(Ord. No. 866, 8-12-81)
   e.   In keeping with the provisions of this Section, the following
procedures shall be followed in accounting for this fund:
      1.   Issue a Receipt, General Form No. 352, for each fee collected.
      2.   Remit receipts to the Clerk-Treasurer at least once a month.
      3.   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue an official receipt for remittance
specifying on such receipt the number of general receipts accounted for. (For
example: General Receipt Nos. 1-8, $32.00)
      4.   The Clerk-Treasurer shall receipt the fees to a separate fund in the
ledger of receipts and disbursements and deposit such receipts in the Town's
general corporation bank account.
      5.   Monies from this fund may be invested by the Clerk-Treasurer and the
interest shall be placed in the General Operating Fund.
(Schererville Town Code § 3-6-3).
Sec. 4-203 Fees for Applications to Police Department.
   a.   The Resolution of the Metropolitan Police Commission is adopted and a
twenty dollar ($20.00) fee shall be assessed to any and all applicants for the
position of a police officer with the Town of Schererville, Indiana.
   b.   The twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee shall be paid directly to the
Police Department by each prospective applicant.
(Ord. No. 1369, § 2, 2-12-97; Ord. No. 1451, § 1, 2-10-99)
   c.   The twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee shall be placed into the Police
Department Equipment fund.
(Ord. No. 1369, §§ 1-3, 2-12-97; Ord. No. 1451, § 3, 2-10-99)
Sec. 4-204 Incident Reports, Accident Reports, Photographs, Vehicle
Identification Number Checks, Video Tapes and Audio Tapes.
   a.   The Metropolitan Police Department shall charge fees for the following
services, which shall be furnished to any person entitled to receive said
information:
      1.   Incidents reports: $.10 per page.
      2.   Accident reports: $8.00.
      3.   Photographs: $7.00.
      4.   Vehicle identification number checks: $5.00.
      5.   Video tapes: $2.00.
      6.   Audio tapes: $1.00.
   b.   All fees for incident reports, accident reports, photographs, vehicle
identification number checks, video tapes and audio tapes shall be deposited
into the Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund (LECEF).
(Ord. No. 1533, 8-8-01; Ord. No. 1713, § 1, 8-8-07)
Sec. 4-204A Miscellaneous Fees.
   a.   Vehicle tow release fee. A forty dollar ($40.00) fee shall be assessed
and collected for any vehicle tow release performed by the Town of Schererville
Police Department. The processing of the fee shall be in conformance with the
applicable requirements of the State of Indiana Board of Accounts, as amended
from time to time. The fee shall be paid directly to the Town Police Department
and deposited in the Police Department Special Revenue Non-reverting Equipment
Fund.
   b.   Unclaimed vehicle fee. Any authorized vehicle tow company which obtains
the appropriate and legal right and title to a car or vehicle towed at the
request of the Town of Schererville Police Department, and then sells or
“scraps” that car or vehicle, shall be assessed an unclaimed vehicle fee of
forty dollars ($40.00). The fee shall be paid directly to the Town Police
Department and deposited in the Police Department Special Revenue Non-Reverting
Equipment Fund. (Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 12-11-02; Ord. No. 1688, § 1, 12-13-06;
Ord. No. 1993, § 1, 5-10-23)
   c.   Fingerprint Service Fee. A fifteen dollar ($15.00) fee shall be
assessed and collected for any fingerprint services performed by the Town of
Schererville Police Department. The processing of the fee shall be in
conformance with the applicable requirements of the State of Indiana Board of
Accounts, as amended from time to time. The fee shall be paid directly to the
Town Police Department and deposited in the Law Enforcement Continuing
Education Fund.
(Ord. No. 1565, § 1, 12-11-02; Ord. No. 1686, § 1, 12-13-06)
Sec. 4-204B Law Enforcement Processing Service Charge and Release Fee.
   a.   In order to support the administrative and processing responsibilities
of the Metropolitan Police Department, as well as for the convenience provided
and associated with processing the receipt of cash or surety bonds connected
with a criminal charge or offense for which the posting of a bond in lieu of
incarceration is a lawful option, there is hereby authorized and established a
special user fee, to be known as Schererville Police Department Law Enforcement
Processing Service Charge and Release Fee.
   b.   The Schererville Police Department Law Enforcement Processing Service
Charge and Release Fee hereinafter identified may be collected by the
Metropolitan Police Department in each instance of providing additional
processing and release services for persons charged with criminal offenses for
which they have been placed under lawful arrest and whereby the posting of a
bond in lieu of incarceration is a lawful option. The Schererville Police
Department Law Enforcement Processing Service Charge and Release Fee shall be
charged at the same time the bond is collected.
   c.   The Schererville Police Department Law Enforcement Processing Service
Charge and Release Fee shall be initially established in the amount of $35.00,
which is hereby deemed to be a reasonable and just amount, and reasonably
related to the administration of the law enforcement services as specified
hereinabove.
   d.   All Schererville Police Department Law Enforcement Processing Service
Charge and Release Fee remitted to the Metropolitan Police Department shall be
deposited with the office of the Town Clerk-Treasurer and credited to the
Schererville Police Department Law Enforcement Processing Service Charge and
Release Fee Special Revenue Non-Reverting Fund established by separate town
ordinance as such exists or may be amended from time to time hereinafter in
conformance with applicable law.
(Ord. No. 1819, 9-12-12)
Division XVI. Miscellaneous Fees.
Sec. 4-205 Assessment Registration.
   a.   Owners of property subject to I.C., § 6-1.1-5-15 shall not be required
to file an assessment registration notice with the Town of Schererville on
behalf of the Township Assessor.
(Ord. No. 1279, § l, 5-11-94)
   b.   The owner of property subject to I.C., § 6-1.1-5-14, or the person
performing the work on behalf of the owner, who has obtained a permit from the
Town of Schererville for said work, shall not be required to pay a five-dollar
($5.00) fee for the filing of an assessment registration notice.
(Ord. No. 1279, § 2, 5-11-94)
Sec. 4-206 Fees Charged by the Plat Review Committee.  8
   The following fee schedule is approved and adopted and is effective from
this date:
      Establishing lot-of-record from metes and bounds legal
description   $50.00
      Creation of one (1) lot subdivision (Commercial or Residential)   $75.00
      Creation of two (2) lot subdivision (Commercial or Residential)   $100.00
      Zoning Fee (Per Petition)                  $25.00
(Ord. No. 1287, 8-22-94)
